Also, I think the whole topic is a little more complicated than you present it
https://www.heartland.org/news-opinion/news/climate-skeptics-are-more-eco-friendly-than-climate-worriers-study-finds

The study was done using Mechanical Turk, where the users may simply be clicking through the survey rapidly without giving it much attention. Second it is self reported so there are a host of problems that might creep in. On to my own read. Their three groups skeptics, cautiously worried, and highly concerned are not defined in the obvious way by an answer to a particular set of questions. Instead the groups are defied by how there beliefs changed over the course of the study, but no reason for change (other then seasons) is suggested. This opens a number of possibilities for the groupings: perhaps people who click through randomly, for example are classed together.  The structure of the test is ver poorly motivated as a change in belief over time this question they seem to be answering doesn’t obviously require repeated studies. This tells me they were probably looking at a different question when the study started. This is typical of PhD projects ( I think this is the lead authors dissertion) where the research doesn’t show anything else that is interesting. But such data minding opens a host of other possibilities much most notably comparison problems.

If we cannot even successfully implement simple universal face mask protocols to control the rapid spread of the increasingly contagious Covid virus, then what chance do we have in stemming the progression of global warming? Can we act in our own best interests, or has fear has generated such a strong ‘us vs them’ tribal response in ourselves that rational cooperation is unlikely? How much has our innate survival instinct been co-opted by fear and its allies, denial and anger.

Anger and hatred makes one feel stronger and is but a temporary antidote to feeling fearful and weak. It’s what ‘moves in and takes over’ when denial isn’t enough by itself to assuage one’s fears. But the reality of the danger keeps ‘rearing its ugly head’ and the ever increasing levels of angst and the resultant anger ‘boils over’ into overt displays.

Example: Global warming calls for the curtailing of fossil fuel consumption & the Covid pandemic requires the implementation of public health protocols to combat the Covid virus.  Both of these issues are resisted by rigid thinkers. Denial of the source of these dangers in order to ‘combat fear’ actually winds up increasing the dangers. This further increases fear levels, which then ramps up denial, which results in even more danger. The vicious cycle continues until a ‘shit storm’ finally manifests. And when two or more such storms merge and become one, a ‘perfect storm’ ensues, such as the Summer 2020 riots which resulted from the combined angst concerning global warming, the Covid pandemic and a host of social issues (e.g.. policing problems). And this is just one spiral in a building global storm.

I've been looking into the maths of this subject for a while now. This is what I've found.

The Earth's Greenhouse effect of 34C is entirely a product of assuming the energy balance applies at the surface. The immediate question is why do we assume sea level is the correct surface? Why not include the sea bed, the average altitude of dry land, the tropopause or the clouds? All of these could arguably be a "surface".

Yet if we look at every world in the solar system that has an atmosphere we don't find a balance at 1 bar of pressure (Earth sea level pressure) anywhere. It is always higher up than that. The closest match is the top of the main cloud systems. Perhaps that represents the effective reach of atmospheric circulation for this problem.

The actual temperature balance for Earth is at about 5km up which is roughly consistent with the above. What this means is that the actual Greenhouse effect is much smaller than 34C. My hunch is that its in the bottom third of that range, 10C to 0C. That's right, it might be that it is actually zero and this whole business is based on applying the equations at the wrong altitude.

The temperature at any other altitude is then due to the lapse rate which is simply the normal temperature gradient you get going up or down through the atmosphere.

I have noticed that CO2 tends to emit radiation higher up the atmosphere but that does not mean heat lower down is "trapped". Also we don't know what the actual relationship between CO2 and temperature is, it is very difficult to claim that either one causes the other.

What about the graphs that show runaway rising temperatures? If you look at the sources they nearly always quote Marcott and Hadcrut. These are different, one is low frequency so it does not include decades long warming, the other is high frequency so it does. The main reason the graphs look different is that they represent different methods of dealing with the data.

Other graphs of past temperatures exist and they show a range of results. Alley and Mann for example show previous warm periods that look very like ours.

Overall it looks is if there are good reasons to doubt the doomsday messages and also to doubt large parts of the science, or to be more accurate the assumptions behind it and the way it is presented to us.
The energy balance does not apply on the surface, instead it is in the higher atmosphere.

Climate change is any significant long-term change in the expected patterns of average weather of a region (or the whole Earth) over a significant period of time. Basically the difference in Earths global and/or regional climate over time. Climate change is about the abnormal variations to the climate, and the effects of these variations on other parts of the Earth. Again this can be measured. Natural causes (also measurable) alone cannot explain all of these changes. Meaning human activities are contributing to climate change, primarily by releasing billions of tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) and other heat-trapping gases (aka greenhouse gases). Greenhouse gases are accumulating in Earth's atmosphere and again as a result of human activities, causing surface air temperatures and subsurface ocean temperatures to rise. Again this can be measured. The current warming trend (from greenhouse gas emissions) is of particular significance because most of it is the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia. Satellites and other technologies have been used by scientists  to collect data and information regarding current and past climate. Evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming. And according to data we should be in the ice-age-recovery warming but we’re not because humans. This will in result cause many problems on a global scale.

Hey man. I'm center-right in ideological worldview. I am an individualist, I hate the government, and I think supporting corporations is important because 90% of corporarions are small businesses and people working tirelessly to build up their own part of the world is incredible and needs to be supported.

All of that said, I believe in climate change and think something needs to be done about it. However, when folks left of center try to have this conversation - they often assume the only solution is through the government. This is dangerous and shuts down dialogue. Scientific consensus on the issue of climate change =/= consensus on policy prescription. I find a lot of the time that people left of center will call folks client change deniers when they do not believe a carbon tax will work, but do believe climate change is a problem that needs to be addressed now. This is harmful to the discussion from your side of the isle. When discussing ideological "poisoning of the well" - the left has a huge blind spot in the tactics that they use to do the same types of things they disdain in the right.

Personally, I think that technological innovation will bring us out of this. If enough businesses have the funds and resources for R&D, then they will have an economic incentive to develop something that tackles this issue. I think that slapping a carbon tax on the industry might delay the effects of climate change, but ultimately prohibit it from being resolved in a timely manner - which is what we all want, right? If we extend the duration of a solution, it might not come about in time. It's like placing a bandaid on a slit throat. We need to figure out a way to stitch the artery now - not waste time with the bandaid. Taking money out of the pockets of people who can actually develop that technology right now is a net negative, imo.

I think the left has a tendency to focus in on the bad apples in the group. The Bill and Melinda Gates foundation wouldn't exist with the policies y'all push. I also find that the policies don't accomplish the things you hope that they do. People on the left have this disdain for large corporations, but then place their hope in the largest, most corrupt monopolistic enterprise that has ever existed - the government. It makes no sense to me.

To clarify this point - people become cynical when you present a crisis and imply you know the solution's correct policy prescription when presenting scientific facts. It's hard for some people to accept that this isn't just another tactic to increase taxes.

I don't understand how CO2 can not have an effect. 

Looking at its EM absorption and emission spectrums makes it pretty clear that increasing CO2 in an atmosphere under a sun should lead to a temperature increase.

That in turn should yield an increase in water in the air, which is even more of a green house gas. 

The water and CO2 increase *should* , in turn, yield more trees and other plant life which help lower the temperatures.

However we're clearing out the forests faster than they can recover so the number of trees is artificially being forced down as the heating contributors are going up.

Net result is a very fast temperature increase over a century that upsets the stability of established animal biomes, potentially leading to a starvation ripple through the food chain.

That's what we want to avoid and the most logical way is to slow down the temperature change which can be done by simply cutting our reliance on fossil fuels by hurting the profitability of it.

That's the rub and that's why there's so much disinfo around climate change.

People fight against the science of climate change (which I fully accept) for many reasons: disbelief, fear, the fact that political partisans use the scientific reality to push their favourite policies etc etc etc. 


The first step to convincing climate skeptics is to treat them as logical people that have a different weighing of the metrics to ourselves and calmly try to explain why they might want to re-think. Moralising, screeching and denigrating these people isn't the way forward in my opinion.


As scientists, we also need to keep the discussion on the science and stop suggesting that the science is automatically policy prescriptive. It is not and that is not science. The IPCC are very clear on this point and in their reports.


"Solving" climate change will require policies that command broad based support that transcends the traditional political boundaries. Emphasising these boundaries and blaming them for inaction on climate change is an interesting way to go...

Now, the video... I strongly suspect this was an April fools joke. Since neither the youtube video nor the news broadcaster within it contain any actual sources, I think this is a reasonable conclusion.
You see, electrolysis is not a newly patented method of extracting energy from water. What it does is separate the hydrogen from the oxygen, which can then be burned as fuel. The problem is that electrolysis requires at least as much energy as burning the resulting hydrogen gives, thanks to those pesky laws of thermodynamics.
But by far the biggest hint that this was a joke of deception is that they describe this new fuel as HHO. I.e. Hydrogen, hydrogen, oxygen. Aka H2O, aka water. The thing that is being said (by your source!) is that he turns water into water by electrolysis, which somehow gives free energy, rather than costing energy.

I don't believe in Man Made Climate Change but I liked this video, would be great to have discussions with people on this without being attacked, personally I would add: 
1) Don't say "the science is settled", science is about constantly challenging assumptions and re-testing hypotheses when new information becomes available. We have been studying the human body for 100's of years and are still unsure whether saturated fat is good or bad for you, the climate involves infinitely more complex systems and integration of different scientific disciplines yet you think this particular area has been "settled"?? We're still arguing about the number of planets in our solar system, the number of elements on the periodic table... ​@David Ansty Thanks for your reply. 
"Even if the globe had warmed at all it would be a good thing." 
I live in a colder climate and love summer, so it's easy for my mind to think that warmer weather would be better.. because I would enjoy it personally. I took a walk yesterday on a 57 degree day in Northeast Ohio on December 9th. Very pleasant for ME at that moment. And I think the odds are good you consume other sources of information that tell you a warmer planet would be a good thing and that "CO2 is plant food."


Unfortunately, the reality is far more complicated than that. All life on Earth has been adapted to cooler global temps for thousands of years and much lower CO2 levels for the last 800,000 years, and life does best when the conditions it evolved it stay in place, or if they do change, they change VERY slowly. 


Life IS adaptable, but it can only adapt so fast, and we are warming the planet 10-20 times faster than when coming out of an ice age, and we have increased the acidity of the oceans by 30% in the blink of an eye in terms of geological time. 


So what has happened five times before on Earth when there were very rapid changes in temperatures, CO2 levels, or other living conditions? Mass extinctions of life. The last time the planet warmed this rapidly (and oceans absorbed lots more CO2),  over 90% of life in the oceans went extinct, as did over 70% of life on land, including everything over 90 pounds. 


Rapid warming (and increased CO2) set in motion hundreds of ripple effects that upset the delicate equilibrium of life, leading to mass die-offs of species. Air that is 1 degree C warming can hold 7% more moisture, so the atmosphere sucks up moisture from some places (like the American west) more than before and dumps it elsewhere, creating worsening droughts, wildfires, storms (more CAT 5 hurricanes), and floods (several "once in every 500-year floods" just in the last 5 years"). With drier soil, the trees in the Rockies got stressed and less able to fight disease and insects, and warmer temps allowed the spread of two species of bark beetles that feed on trees. So all of a sudden, you have more than 800 million "standing dead" trees in Colorado alone:


https://www.denverpost.com/2017/02/15/dead-trees-colorado-forests/


Sure, more CO2 creates more greening in some places, but guess what the "CO2 is plant food" folks like Matt Ridley didn't tell you?  Crops grow thicker leaves, so they require more water, at even at 1 degree of warming, staple crops have lost 5-8% of several key nutrients. And guess what happens when people eat less nutrient-dense foods? More obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and more and more of our personal and national budgets get drained to fix sick bodies instead of just for living. 


As temps have warmed, the corn belt has moved over 100 miles northward in the US and the boundary between the warm dry west and cool moist east has moved 140 miles eastward. As these boundaries shift, areas that have been the bread basket of the US and the world will become less and less able to provide the crops they used to provide. Scientists estimate that 60% of the world's wheat crop will be in trouble by 2100, and because the changes we have set in motion are non-linear changes (our rate of greenhouse gas emissions has been doubling every 25 years), that's probably a conservative estimate). 


https://www.commondreams.org/news/2019/09/26/new-research-warns-severe-climate-related-droughts-could-threaten-60-global-wheat


Meanwhile, the warming and acidification of the oceans has slowed ocean currents, has already reduced slightly the amount of oxygen in the water, and has caused mass die-offs of coral reefs, the rainforests of the oceans: 


https://www.cbsnews.com/news/great-barrier-reef-australia-downgrades-outlook-coral-very-poor-ocean-warming-today-2019-08-30/


https://weather.com/science/environment/news/2019-07-31-guam-coral-reefs-bleaching


As the reefs go, many fish species that depend on the reefs will reduce in numbers or even go extinct, and on the path we are on, virtually all coral reefs are expected to be dead by 2100. A recent study showed that in the last 2 decades, New England lost 16% of its fishing jobs due to global warming and climate disruption:


https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/12/191209161317.htm


That trend will continue if we keep destroying the marine ecosystems, and on the other end of the spectrum, ski season is getting shorter and shorter, reducing income and jobs. Around here, ski season should have started two weeks ago, but there's no weather in sight cold enough for them to make snow and keep it on the slopes. All the while, we'll be paying more and more out of pocket to fix the damage from worsening droughts, floods, and wildfires. 


I'm guessing you're used to climate debates where one side says it's all a leftist tax scam and CO2 is plant food (but those folks don't know the research) and the other side says the science is clear and the deniers are anti-science idiots (but most of those folks don't know the research either, so their faith in the scientists sounds more like a religion). That's not a very productive discussion. I'm a university researcher who for more than a decade has been researching and writing a book about why the health of society and the planet are unraveling, and what we need to do to heal them. I've read thousands of sources, discussed and debated with thousands of people (helpful for finding out what you don't know), and I'm sorry to report that the threats from global warming and climate disruption are real, man-made, lethal, and urgent. But they are not urgent in the sense of a lion running at you or a hurricane that will make landfall tomorrow, so the human brain struggles to grasp them. Life on Earth WON'T end in 2030 if we don't cut greenhouse gas emissions 50% by then, but  the real problem is that our actions today (me driving and heating my house with fossil fuels) is setting in motion chain reactions that unfolds over decades, centuries, and even millennia. And if we don't stop global warming soon (and reverse it), we will pass certain tipping points where we get runaway warming and ice melt and climate disruption. If that happens, we may be powerless to stop the changes until the Earth gets 5-8 degrees C warmer (9-14 degrees F). If that happens, much of the Earth will become unlivable, uninhabitable, and long before we get there, we'll be looking at hundreds of millions of climate refugees that will overwhelm nations' ability to cope (that big Syrian refugee crisis was only 1 million people). 


So, that's just a tiny fraction of the big-picture devastation that we are heading for if we keep burning fossil fuels and warming the planet (while also polluting it and destroying wilderness habitat): Gradual and sometimes sudden collapse of the ecosystems that human life depends on, resulting in the degradation then collapse of civilizations, and hundreds of millions to billions of human deaths. We recklessly overspent our Earth budget, and forgot that our lives depend on the health of  the Earth's ecosystems. We upset the apple cart, so now we are literally in a race for the long-term survival of human civilization. 


Take care.

Actually, I've never seen any such statistics, but what I have seen are statistics that people who don't understand the science get fooled by--and thus conclude AGW isn't real. Speaking as a researcher who is working on a book that is partly about global warming, we know that the climate emergency is real, lethal, urgent, and WE caused it. How do we know human activity is the main cause of almost all recent global warming? If the theory of man-made global warming is true, science should be able to verify that several things happen: 

1) Burning fossil fuels should increase the levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) in the atmosphere and oceans. 
2) If the additional CO2 in the atmosphere was mostly due to human activity, the relative proportion of carbon 12/carbon 13 isotopes in the atmosphere should gradually shift towards the ratio produced by burning fossil fuels (2% more Carbon 12). 
3) After human activity has markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the lower atmosphere and the oceans should get warmer than before. 
4) After human activity has markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the upper atmosphere should get cooler. 
5) After human activity has markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there should be an increase in the lower atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. 
6) After human activity has markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there should be a decrease in the upper atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. 
7) Models of the relationship between levels of greenhouse gases and average global temperatures should predict global warming with reasonable accuracy. 
8) Research that takes into consideration the effects of multiple natural factors (sun’s activity, earth’s orbit, etc.) and anthropogenic (man-made) factors on global temperatures should find that the addition of greenhouse gases due to burning fossil fuels contributed to a substantial degree to the amount of warming that has been observed. 

ALL EIGHT of those predictions of climate science (plus others) have been confirmed by research. For #7, while some early models overestimated the impact of more CO2, after they made that adjustment to the models, numerous models have been quite accurate, including models from the early 1980s. Thus, the fingerprints of global warming caused by us burning fossil fuels are all over the thermal content and the CO2 volume and the CO2 composition of the lower and upper atmosphere. Therefore, we have incredibly solid proof that recent warming was caused by us burning fossil fuels.


To dip your toes into the evidence, try all three levels of content in the link below, but especially see Figures 4b, c, and d in the “Advanced” level: 

https://skepticalscience.com/empirical-evidence-for-co2-enhanced-greenhouse-effect-advanced.htm

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2004/12/how-do-we-know-that-recent-cosub2sub-increases-are-due-to-human-activities-updated/

Also see

https://www.theguardian.com/science/2019/jul/24/scientific-consensus-on-humans-causing-global-warming-passes-99

Finally, it’s the SPEED of temperature and CO2 changes which is so lethal to the web of life—TEN TIMES faster than when coming out of an ice age. Most life can’t adapt to the rapid and cascading changes that brings, and our civilization is totally unprepared for the tsunami of rapid and harmful changes coming our way in the next century (but already beginning now). 

If we stay on the path we are on, that leads towards mass die-offs and extinctions of most human and planetary life. I’m almost 60, have two young adult kids, generally care about people and nature, and wish we didn’t do this, but we did. 

Happily, there are hundreds of strategies for healing and restoring a healthy balance, but we will need to switch to lifestyles and an economic model that actually obey the limits and laws of nature. That includes a RAPID transition away from burning fossil fuels and simpler lifestyles in wealthy nations (especially for the rich folks whose lifestyles cause by far the most damage).

Take care.

Dr. Mann's Penn State Hockey stick climate graph took off in the 1980's, which indicated global warming. But I moved near a Penn State branch campus in 1981. I first noticed that the climatology weather station was in the corner of a parking lot, as far from the buildings and cars as possible, and surrounded on 3 sides by a meadow.  It seemed to me the best place for such a weather station -- as far from the buildings and cars as possible.  The next year, however, they moved the climate station to the middle of the parking lot, next to a big building, and directly underneath a big air conditioning exhaust far.  At the time, I simply thought that the temperature readings might be a few degrees warmer now, but the students could dash outside without their coats, write down some data on their clipboards, and go back inside in the winter.  What if they moved the climate stations to a warmer spot at all 20 Penn State campuses across the state?
There are weather stations all over the world and both the urban ones and rural ones show the same warming--as does the data from the oceans.

One important thing to note is that people can't always change their mind overnight. There is an illusion that we control our belief systems and can change them if we wish. This is not the case. Instead, find out what falsities they may have too easily trusted in and plant seeds of doubt with a compelling narrative backed by the evidence. Encourage skepticism and curiosity so that they can find the answers themselves. I went to a private Christian school for all of elementary and middle school, and when I was about 11 or 12, a lecturer came to our school and talked about how climate change wasn’t real and that it was just a natural progression of the cycle of the earth. He showed a lot of data, and my parents aren’t climate change deniers per say, but they also don’t feel strongly that we need to do anything to protect the earth so they didn’t set me straight. The lecturer also taught about a 6000 year old earth and stuff like that. I firmly believed everything he said until I got to college. By then, I was starting to doubt some of what he said and was ready to hear about what other people’s opinions of these things was. Luckily, I had a few professors who set me straight, and I got to do some projects for different classes that forced me to do research. I’m glad now I know the facts about climate change and other things I was taught as a young child that I no longer believe. I am still a Christian, but I don’t put on blinders and think that humanity was meant to destroy the earth in the way we have. I believe good stewardship of what God has given to humanity is to take care of it and preserve it. However, as someone who used to believe all of climate change was a hoax, I understand the arguments they make and how hard it can be to change someone’s mind.

The debate that asks the question "is the global climate changing" is over. The global climate is changing, but the actual question of whether or not man's industrial and fossil fuel burning activities have contributed towards 'causing' the global climate to undergo the changes we are now experiencing is not an easy question to answer, but I think the evidence does point towards them doing so.

We have been burning fossil fuels intensely since the dawn of the industrial revolution almost 300 years ago, and over that period of time, we have increased our CO2 production exponentially year on year, especially as other countries began their own industrial revolution. We have not stopped increasing our CO2 production with each passing year. All that CO2 is not from natural occurrences, but from man's manufactured occurrences. All of it is 'extra' to natural phases of CO2 production, so of course, it cannot be denied that we have contributed (300 years worth) to the current levels of CO2.

With having so much CO2 around, the earth's natural carbon sinks are quite saturated and are unable to take in CO2 at levels that make much of a difference, so more CO2 is in the atmosphere than what is normally present. This warms the air, and along with the sun's constant solar radiation, the energy in the atmosphere increases which leads to more intense weather systems propagating stronger storms and greater precipitation, especially in areas where the climate tends to be more 'moderate'. What we are experiencing and witnessing today are changes to local weather systems that normally worked pretty clock-work like, that were stable and moderate within a fine-tuning. It is the fine-tuning that is breaking down, and is the first symptom of climate change.

I predict that as the atmosphere warms further, leading to greater land ice melting and finding its way into the sea, not only will there be loss of coastal regions as the seas rise, but we should be able to detect the sea rises at geographical places where the seas are channelled (bottle-necked) between landmasses, rises in sea levels will be focused at these points around the world first. Sea level rises will lead to greater amounts of precipitation over land masses, where more frequent flooding will be experienced each year.

You can argue all you want about causes of climate change, but the fact is...it is happening, and it will only become more intense. If the industrial revolution had never occurred, there would not be 300 years worth of 'extra' CO2 in the natural carbon sinks and atmosphere.

If there is one statement that really pisses me off is the 'we have to save the planet' bullshit. We are not saving the planet, we are looking to save the environments of our current habitats from being overwhelmed by events rapid in their occurrence. We can deal with slow catastrophic events, and also catastrophic events that occur in small local regions, but fast, wider-ranging events can knock us for six, and put great stressors upon our social and technological infrastructures. Just bear in mind that our greatest fragility is being dependent on electricity always available at the press of a switch, and that means that every single one of us who have commented on this thread could not handle the loss of electricity for up to just six months, let alone it disappearing forever.

@J P Your new comment is somehow more logically bankrupt than your last one; that's okay... I'll help you out again. 

“lmfao i'm not going to touch base on anything besides your claims of the USA, although it's quite comical to see you have no valid credentials”

This is an Appeal to Authority Fallacy. A statement is valid on it's own merits, not the merits of those who state it; this is logic 101. 

“Now, the united states overall has taken the most drastic steps in order to reduce emissions”

False. The USA is close to dead last when it comes to renewable energy; only being powered by about 10% of it, and having the highest CO2 emissions per capita in the world, compared to other developed countries which are powered by between 40% to 100%. 

“which is varifiable”

It's not variable because based according to a REN21 report on renewable energy in every country in the world, the USA is powered by about 10% renewable energy, compared to... let's check the data. Canada... 70%, Norway... 96%, Brazil 80%, and the list is quite endless. 

“Pay attention when i say overall. Your examples are poor, and of lower industrial capability and capita”

This sentence is incoherent; however, I will say that the USA is the world leader in CO2 emissions per capita. 

“What "pruge of environmental protections"?

Seriously? According to an analysis by  NADJA POPOVICH earlier this year, the Trump administration has removed 10 Air Pollution and Emissions regulations, 9 drilling and extraction regulations, 12 infrastructure and planning regulation, 9 animal protection regulations, 4 toxic substances and safety regulations, and 5 water pollution regulations. It's also important to know that there are currently 32 more regulation purges that are still pending; hopefully they get cancelled somehow. 

“They've gotten stronger if anything”

Not sure how you can make something stronger by getting rid of it. 

“Now, "renewable" energy is quite an interesting subject, and can be pretty comical given who you're discussing with. You for one don't seem to understand the massive environmental impact each form has”

“Nice quotation ("i believe in climate change, but climate science is bullshit"), but we all know quotations only work on a word for word basis, and that is not what i said, nor inferred”

“If you didn't have such a nack for misinterpreting simplistix language, this would have been more productive”


It's not my fault your comments are so philosophically incoherent that it's hardly possible to even understand what you're claiming. Every time I mention some basic science, you disagree with, then claim you're all about science. 

“A HUGE part of climatology has been simulation based. All we know of climate, are events that have passed as late as roday and yesterday”

So you believe in climate change but that underlying scientific method which produced is not very reliable; gotcha. Anyways... you're conflating climate change with global warming. We know that rapid global warming will lead to rapid climate change, even if we cannot predict exactly how drastic the changes will be. Let's ignore climate change for a second and just focus on the fact that global warming will render most of the middle-east uninhabitable, sea levels will rise due to the thermal expansion of ocean, the coral reefs will be purged which will destabilize the ocean's ecosystem, the melting of the permafrost destroying infrastructure and creating yet another positive feedback loop, and of course... climate change, which is the worst effect of global warming.

“You also fail to identify main "subsets" such as helioseismology, meteorolgy, atmosoheric chemistry and science, etc.. geology alone does not determine what influences earth's climate”

This statement is incoherent. Climatology is a subset of geology; geology alone does determine what influences the Earth's climate, because Geology is the study of the Earth, which includes the climatology of the climate, the oceanography of the ocean, the volcanology of volcanoes, and so on. 

“Never denied real science, nor have a inferred such. Your personal opinions do not count as fact”

The scientific literature is not my opinion. Also... the term “real science” seems like a weasel phrase, what is real science if not the studies which exists within the Master Journals of Science? Which by the way... includes the Journal of Climatology.

​@J P The first section of your comment is pure argumentum ad hominem, thus has no value within the context of climate change.

"All you do is parrot the same talking points"

I parrot the scientific literature, which is one demonstrable body of knowledge that only gets more accurate over time. 

"And offer no detailed explanation or actual scientific factor"

You have provided no scientific argument in your comment, just baseless assertions, so brought up that fact tha your assertions don't match the scientific literature.

"When i say global warming and climate change have been used interchangeably for decades, it's rather true, as most do so..."

This is an argumentum ad populum fallacy. 62% of the USA believe the Earth is 6,000 years old; that doesn't refute the vast body of scientific literature which states that it is 4.6 billion years old, for the same reason "most" people are wrong when using global warming and climate change interchangeably. The argument... "It's okay because most people do it" is flawed logic. 

"especially when the word anthropogenic is used"

This is even more false. Global warming is anthropogenic, climate change is caused by global warming. 

"and technicalities don't exactly help your case when that's the base of your argument"

It does help my case because you're providing a definition of global warming that doesn't conform with how the scientific literature describes it. 

"What are your credentials in order to judge percentage of inaccuracy?"

Appeal to Authority Fallacy. 

" Which is usually around 70%"

Depends what it is you're talking about. 

"Funny how other fields of study that correlate are able to determine these vast variables with 90% or better accuracy"

Other fields are not Climatology. 

“"Climate science" is more or less a false narrative”

Climatology, oceanography, volcanology... these are all the same scientific method being applied to different aspects of reality, and are all subsets of geology. Denying one is effectively denying them all. 

“seeing as how it relies heavily on predictions”

The entire point of the scientific method is to make predictions; that's how inductive logic and empiricism works. 

“that have been known to fail”

Depends what you mean by “fail”, all of our predictions were too conservative, we predicted temperatures would rise by 1.4 degrees, but the real number turned out to be 1.7 degrees. 

“It only effectively works off of the events we have gone through”

We predicted that temperatures would rapidly increase, we were correct, but we were off by 0.3 degrees.

“Another major point is how experimentation really only takes place in urban areas, where heat is most certainly greater, and smog thicker”

False. We measure the Earth temperatures in ocean where temperatures are not impacted by such variables. 90% of the Earth's heat is contained in the ocean. 

“Now, if you'd pay attention, i'm not dismissing the reliable side of atmospheric and earth studies...”

Yes you actually are. You just denied the whole scientific method by claiming climatology (aka geology) is unreliable.

“i'm just throwing alarmism out the window, and MSM fear mongering along with it”

The terms “alarmist” and “fear mongering” are just buzzwords with no scientific value. 

“That's rather comical you mention politics, because that's exactly what the UN and IPCC are based on”

Both the IPCC and the UN are the same thing... the UN, and the UN is not a peer reviewed scientific journal. 

“I for one highly doubt you've read any real scientific journals”

What is “journals”? We're talking about the Journal of Climatology; you know... one of the Master Journals of Science?

“You pointing fingers directly at americans (who lead in emission reduction globally)”

False. China and France lead emissions reduction around the world; in fact, the USA produces double the CO2 per capita compared to these countries. I country like Norway is powered by 100% renewable energy is a better example for emission reduction than the USA which has the highest CO2 per capita rate in the world, the USA is powered by about 15% renewable energy last time I checked, and that number might start decreasing with their president's purge of environmental protections over the last few years. 

“Anyone with a few functioning brain cells knows you can't deny climate change”

Sorry but “I believe in climate change, but climate science is bullshit” is an oxymoron. 

“The "scientific method" however is extremely questionable in concern to "climate science", as certain methodology cannot technically be considered science.... a derivative of such, maybe”

Climatology, Volcanology, and Oceanography... all subsets of geology. You cannot deny science when it gives the answers you want, but accept it otherwise.

@J P Not sure how this is possible, but literally 100% of your comment is the exact opposite of reality. Let's correct everything. 


"global warming and climate change have been used interchangeably decades"


False. Global warming was discovered in 1896 by a Swedish scientists who conducted an experiment designed to measure the impacts of trains at the time, it later discovered in 1930s that global warming is causing climate change. 


"Overall it doesn't take away from "hotspots" caused by human activity. Technically not a global phenomenon"


Sorry... "technically the warming of the globe is not global warming" is an oxymoron. Let's recap... global warming is the warming of the glove, climate change is the changing of the climate. Very simple. 


"Existing datasets are modified when results vary far too much with major inaccuracies as told by methodology sections"


This is a incoherent word salad with no quantified criteria of accuracy. The term "inaccuracies" has no value until you define what accurate is. Is 98% inaccurate? 92% Inaccurate? "when real scientific research is conducted"


There are 20,000 peer reviewed scientific studies confirming climate change. 


"the issue isn't anywhere near as bad as alarmists claim"


The term "alarmist" has no value; the peer reviewed scientific literature states that the Earth is warming at 1.7 degrees per 100 years; whether that's "not as bad" as your anecdotes is irrelevant, science doesn't care about your emotions. 


"and existing datasets aren't modified in order to create a desired, agenda based outcome"


You just said they were, now you're back tracking. 


"Abstractions have their time and place"


Yeah... when data is being sampled. 


"The desired outcome is that of a fear mongering nature"


There's no such thing as "fear mongering nature"


"The overall goal and solution of the UN is global taxation"


The solution to the problem is off-context from the problem itself. 


"So now it's 20,000, huh? Funny how the numbers ALWAYS vary with every response"


I only mentioned the vast body of scientific literature on climate change once in my earlier comments; therefore your claim is malformed logic. I say "20,000" because the vast body of knowledge on climate change is constantly growing, it could be 21,493 studies, it could be 23,483 studies, so I just say 20,000 to make it easier. 


"It's rather evident you've never read an actual scientific journal with attention to methodology"


My understanding of these topics comes from scientific literature. I've yet to read a peer reviewed scientific study that agrees with the bullshit American political hacks say. Most of the claims I hear are not just a denial of climate change, it's a denial of the scientific method entirely.

@J P Okay you're failing to comprehend my inference to your science denial; I'll break things down with more detail. 


"Except y'know, anthropogenic climate change"


You're conflating global warming with climate change; it's global warming that is anthropogenic, climate change are the effects of global warming. 


"climate change models are computer based"


Predicting the climate requires trillions of calculations, therefore computer based models are the most accurate. Global warming however is not based on computer models, global warming is very easy to measure. Even if we cannot predict the exact degree of climate change, we know that a rapid rise in global temperature will have a significant effect on the climate regardless. What you're saying is analogous to... "Our computer models cannot predict the exact location the meteor will hit, therefore the meteor doesn't exist"


"with admitted modified data"


What is "admitted modified data"? You do realize that modifying data is a good thing right? We us abstractions to make data more accurate. 


" to produce desired outcomes"


The desired outcome of modifying data is to acquire accurate data. 


"and widely have non-repeatable experimentation"


Which of the 20,000 peer reviewed scientific studies proving climate change include non-repeatable experimentation?

Climate change is a hoax. It's funny when people talk about "the overwhelming scientific consensus", and yet they don't know a damn thing about the science. 1) The earth has been continually warming since the end of the Little Ice Age in 1850. This predates the invention of the internal combustion engine. 2) Atmospheric CO2 does not heat the atmosphere in a linear fashion, but rather logarithmically. If doubling CO2 causes 2 degrees higher temperatures, then you'd have to quadruple CO2 to get 2 more degrees higher temperatures. Ice core samples show that atmospheric CO2 has been as high as 8000ppm, and yet everything was fine. 3) Global temperatures and atmospheric CO2 is not highly correlated. In earth's past temperatures have gone down as CO2 went up and vice versa. The evidence shows that CO2 actually follows global temperatures, so it would be more correct to say that higher global temperatures causes higher CO2, rather than the other way around. 4) It was warmer during the Middle Ages than it is now. Historically, the earth has been much warmer, and we're in one of the coldest periods of the Holocene (the last 11,000 years of earth's history).

@Franz Maier 1) No, it hasn't. In the earth's past, there have been massive swings in global temperatures and CO2, in as little as 20 years. Historically, most changes were not very gradual, but quite sudden. 

2) Not really. During the Ice Age, sea levels were so low that the eastern coast of the USA extended some 5 miles further out into sea. An entire island the size of Germany was swallowed up in the North Sea. And yet, humanity and life itself seemed to be just fine. With modern technology, keeping the sea at bay is achievable. Just ask the Danes. This is no reason to wish for a colder climate, when a colder climate makes the earth less habitable for life. 

3) Yes, other factors can influence the climate. How do you know they're not at work right now? Does anyone really know what caused the Ice Age? Or what caused it to end? Leading scientists who work in the field have a few theories, but nothing close to a consensus. In the past, global temperatures have increased while CO2 dropped and vice versa. You can't tell me CO2 is causing global temperatures to rise when we have evidence that global temperatures have risen in the paste while CO2 went down. 

4) The earth being warmer would be a great benefit to all life on the planet. Anyone who's observed the changing seasons can tell you that. The warmer the planet, the fewer things die, and all life is better able to survive the harshness of winter.

1. The speed has increased.

2. Was it really fine though? Sea levels were substantially higher. If climate was to change to that state, the vast majority of humans would be displaced in the process. It would be a catastrophe.

3. There are other factors that can influence climate. However, they are not at work right now. The effect CO2 has on the energy balance of the planet can be measured. The causality is directly observable.
Historically, CO2 increase both lagged and lead temperature increase. Two things can cause each other respectively, you know.

4. It wasn't, at least not globally.
The earth has indeed been much warmer in the past, too bad that doesn't help us at all.

As a very nostalgic teenager, there are a couple of things that would have reached me. The first is a tragic country song comparing the earth to a woman who is ravaged and destroyed. The second is a Terry Tempest Williams book, and anything similar to that. I didn't need a man being angry or condemnatory or acting smarter than me. I needed a wise, kind woman who could help me feel that being a woman is a good thing. I needed a woman to show me how to do an adult version of the spiritual connection to the earth I saw in Pocahontas. I needed a man (specifically a cowboy or conservative religious man) to regret his greed and control over the earth and women.

Imagine for a while that you are someone else. Here is your alternative life history (which was actually mine). At five years old, you liked getting up early to watch captain planet. You liked your Pocahontas shirt. You felt safe and spiritual listening to the wise Grandmother Willow and the Colors of the Wind song. You felt guilty for liking these things because your parents disapproved of environmentalism. Your mom read an article against global warming while watching your swim lessons. You began homeschooling at age 10. Your last year of public school science was fourth grade. You were a very ill child who found it difficult to learn. You don't remember doing science in fifth grade. At the end of sixth grade you read an Abeka science book on your own. Abeka is a very conservative Christian homeschool curriculum company. You tried to go to public school part time in seventh grade but it didn't work out. You had one semester of science, which taught about electrical circuits, not climate. You used a Creationist book for eighth grade science. The whole book argued against evolution. You didn't do science after that. You learned that science wasn't interesting, and being interested in it would probably create unnecessary conflict with your parents that you didn't have the energy for and besides, you'd always been the obedient oldest child. If you didn't have your parents on your side with your health problems, you were going to be our of luck. You went to community college. You walked into an English class where the teacher announced "Welcome to Environmental English." You were scared. You were probably going to be attacked or made to feel stupid by some angry liberals. Your teacher turns out to be one of the best you've ever had before or since. He calmly teaches you how to read arguments about which power production technologies to use where. He wants you to learn to think. Maybe liberals aren't so bad after all. You still put off biology as long as possible. You transfer from there to a conservative religious university which thankfully still teaches evolution even though many in the religion don't believe in it. You walk into Intro Biology for non-science majors. You were among many students who didn't know that evolution was real. The teacher sucks, but the one lecture where he held up models of skills demonstrating ape to human evolution was neat. It makes you want to learn more later. Years pass. You de-convert from your religion. You start to wonder about science. What about it might be true and interesting, or the opposite. You hear people who probably grew up knowing things you didn't getting frustrated with people like you. You feel put in the middle of a fight between the people you came from and the people you're starting to tentatively like. If you were me, what would you do? How would you like to be spoken to, at various stages of my life? If you've read all this, you deserve a gold star and a coffee.

When I have similar conversations I find you never win in the moment and you usually find that the other party gets more entrenched in their mindset at least for the moment. However I do find that you can make some success by planting seeds that beat climate change denial at its own game (success judged by change in opinion in follow up conversations). 

For instance when I hear that it is too expensive to subsidize green tech and infrastructure I point out that we already heavily subsidize oil production here in Canada and that oil is one of the most capital intensive, labour non intensive industries out there and that it needs to be that way for the companies to keep up the way they have been (for those of you who work in the Alberta oil sands, how much money goes into just the purchase of the heavy mining equipment that was built in other countries vs your annual salary). I contrast this with the amount of Human Resources go into creating a windmill or a solar panel where the labour costs are a significantly higher proportion of the final cost of the product. Labour cost equals jobs and jobs equal families with a wage to live off of. 

Or for people who don’t trust the government. I point out that most researchers work for private companies or universities and that the vast majority of green tech development is being done by private entities. The government just thinks it’s a good idea to support them, much like they have done for oil, gas, and coal. 

And the most important thing that I find you can do is to listen to the other person because they probably have concerns, fears, and misconceptions just like us. It is very easy to become preachy and then nobody listens at all. At the end of the day the goal isn’t to be right, the goal is to show them that believing in the science of climate change is about wanting a good future where our energy comes from much more sustainable sources

There’s an ecological fallacy involved in this conversation. 

Scientists point out data about climate trends which involve large periods of time and data-points, they inherently have to be presented as coherent stories to the public (that’s the only way we can understand them in general).

Then a deduction is made by the inference to either say that x weather event (a distinct data point) supports or invalidates climate change (the large trend of continuous data-points) by either conforming to the story or not conforming to it. 

The fallacy is that we are deducing (producing something certain) from an inference (statistical likelihood). With this you can select and point to any fact and think you disproved or proved climate change.

Now im not gonna argue that climate change is not happening, it is. Im not convinced that humans are the main cause. Im not gonna go that in depth, but Ill give a couple points- please go fact check me! Im mainly using the Greenland Ice cores data.

Over the past 10,000 years the earth has been cooling. There are oscilltions of warmth followed by cold, but overall these oscillations of temperature have been getting colder and colder. It got to the point where in the 1850’s there was more glaciers than theres been since the LAST ICE AGE. Our frame of reference is completely screwy. We arent comparing the temperature to what has been the avg over the past 10,000 yrs. We’re comparing it to the coldest its been in the last 10000 years.

I already mentioned the oscillations of temperature, it is completely normal for the temperature to rise and fall 2 or 3 degrees celsius every couple of hundreds of years and were saying humans are the cause of the increase of 1 degree celsius.

If we’re saying that it is the CO2 were pumping into the air thats causing it, that simply isn’t the case. Were on a completey normal change in temperature. Additionally, if you look at  CO2 levels over the past 150,000 years, you’ll see that they have been relatively constant until the Industrial Revolution. How would you explain every single period of warming and cooling before then? How would you explain the cause of the last ice age and how we came out of it, if CO2 is the reason? Now im not saying this isn’t bad for the environment, I’m also not saying that we aren’t treating our planet like absolute shit. I’m just saying that we aren’t contributing the warming of the planet to the extent (if at all) as we think we are.

I believe in climate change, but treating the opposing side like they're idiots or conflating them to mostly be conservatives is disingenuous at best and stupidly arrogant at worst. Especially since the controversy isn't whether climate change is real or not, but how much human activity is effecting it, which isn't as black and white as say, a non-flat Earth or there being two genders. Just in case you wanted to know why I and others hit Dislike.

Even Skepticalscience.com has it's skeptics.  I do not want to push an agenda for or against climate change.  I disagree partly with the human activity portion. While I agree that we do play a role changes in our environment, the distance our planet is from the sun is the most contributing factor to the temperature of the Earth.  We do not orbit the sun in a perfect circle by any axis, in fact no two cycles are the same. These changes as skeptical science points out indeed take long periods of time, though there are times when temperatures on Earth dropped or rose significantly and abruptly.  The last Ice Age lasted for 2.58 million years, and then in a span of 11,700 years thawed out to where we are today.  Putting that into perspective, when we as humans think that we cause significant climate change to this planet that has been enduring consistently and constantly changing climate patterns.  Of course we are more focused on how climate change effects humans and the environment and not the Earth as a whole.  The fact of the matter is that even if we kill all the cows, stop all the factories, eliminate all CO2 emission, we probably wouldn't put a dent in the current climate patterns.  Significant change to the planet's climate even if every single one of us adopted a green lifestyle would probably not happen before some other natural disaster.  Don't hate on me or be disrespectful, I am only trying to spark a meaningful and respectful debate, because it seems to me that both sides have shaky science to throw at the other side.

Living in Saskatchewan, there is lots of ranting and roaring about how the Carbon Tax is out to destroy our jobs and punish the working man and whatnot. I always return with the fact that we live in the sunniest and windiest province in the country. We have the space and location to be at the forefront of wind and solar energy in the country. Choosing not to sell oil wholesale outside of our province is better for our economy. It also would put us on the leading edge of the energy shift, which is when companies have the greatest potential to make money. I don't know if making the executives of the oil and gas corporations the bad guys helps or not. I know people are angry about it, or at least frustrated, but it usually translates to 'if they got to make money from this industry for the last century, why shouldn't I get to?' No one likes to hear that the company they work for doesn't benefit the workers as much as the executives, but perhaps the potential of working your way up the company makes them less likely to condemn it? I really struggle with trying to understand blue collar, on the ground workers being on the same side as the highly paid upper echelons of the companies they work for.

*Doomsday cult* is an expression used to describe cults which believe in apocalypticism and millenarianism, and can refer both to groups that predict disaster, and to those that attempt to bring it about to destroy the entire of the universe. The expression was first used by sociologist John Lofland in his 1966 study of a group of members of the Unification Church of the United States, Doomsday Cult: A Study of Conversion, Proselytization, and Maintenance of Faith. A classic study of a group with cataclysmic predictions had previously been performed by Leon Festinger and other researchers, and was published in his book When Prophecy Fails: A Social and Psychological Study of a Modern Group That Predicted the Destruction of the World.

Referring to his study, Festinger and later other researchers have attempted to explain the commitment of members to their associated doomsday cult, *even after the prophecies of their leader have turned out to be false* . Festinger explained this phenomenon as part of a coping *mechanism called dissonance reduction* , a form of rationalization. Members often dedicate themselves with *renewed vigor* to the group's cause after a failed prophecy, and rationalize with explanations such as a belief that their actions forestalled the disaster, or a belief in the leader when *the date for disaster is postponed* .

We need to destigmatize nuclear energy. 
It's not a forever alternative but it's clean, green, cheaper, more efficient, and has higher yields. The fear of nuclear "chernobyl" explosions should be put to rest. The science in cooling nuclear rods with things that block *more* radiation as opposed to less when it gets heated is basically the solution to positive feedback loops that cause meltdown making it impossible to reach meltdown. Finally, the nuclear waste produced by these plants can be easily contained but does exist. This is why it can't be a permanent solutions but we as a planet can contain this waste for a few decades without issue; no water pollution, air pollutants, carbon release, or nuclear runoff. This waste will be irradiated for thousands of years but as an interim solution, is the only reliable choice really. Then after solar panels that last longer than a couple years that can be built, repaired, and replaced at sensible cost, that will be a better, perhaps permanent, solution.


As an aside, I wouldn't recommend windmills. If we were to somehow wind farm for the world's energy, taking that energy from the atmosphere, that has unforeseeable effects the same way Carbon emissions does. This is a real thing btw. Wind energy isn't some infinite source. It's taking our planet's climate, reducing it's kinetic energy, and using that. On large scale, it's easy to see why that could easily be a problem.

There is significant corroborating evidence exists to support the observed changes in temperature.  A couple of examples from North America:


Mt. Baker glaciers (which I first visited in 1975) reached their maximum extent of the past century in 1915 which is consistent with the cooling period from 1878 to 1911.  They then retreated during the subsequent warming period. The following cooling period saw strong advancement of the glaciers.  Warming following 1976 resulted in retreat.  The extent of the glaciers now is about the same as in 1950. 

In the other direction, the increases during 1911 to 1938 was caused by anomalous tropical sea surface temperatures which extended warm waters into the far north Atlantic and cooler waters into the eastern Pacific oceans. 30 of the 50 US States and 9 of the 10 Canadian Provinces set record high temperatures during the 1911 to 1938 period which to this point in time have never been exceeded. See Schubert et al (2004) NASA.

@Peter Guest THE MACRO VIEW

The planet earth is a complex and fluid entity. Earth is often, and by most only, thought of as a “solid” planet.  The earth hurtles through space elliptically orbiting its sun, and rotating and wobbling on a tilted axis.  The earth is impacted by the gravities of the sun and the other planets.  The other planets have different periods, and shape of orbit around the sun.  The earth has been evolving for more than 4 billion years. The earth is not in a closed system.  The earth’s energy comes from the sun.  The sun is the most important aspect to climate.

During these 4+ billion years, climate trends have changed numerous times centered around 1) the earth’s position relative to the sun, 2) changes to the activity of the sun, and 3) the earth’s magnetosphere.

As regarding the earth’s relative position, and the orbit, tilt, and wobbliness of the earth (there is a scientific word for “wobbliness” but I can’t recall) there are specific intervals that drive climate being of 100,000 years, 41,000 years and 23,000 years. First mathematically proved by Milanković in the early 1920s, and reconfirmed mathematically most recently by the Spectral Mapping Project in 1989. This was geologically confirmed in the rock record in 2010 (“Links between eccentricity forcing and the 100,000-year glacial cycle”, Nature Geoscience, L.M. Lisiecki, 2010.)

Milanković took previous theories and observations to the next level.  Telescopes have been around for a few hundred years.  A few insightful early astronomers (especially James Croll of Scotland) and geologists during the 1800s had suggested that changes in the earth’s climate were a result of astronomical forces and this is what caused the ice ages on earth (or as some like to call them, the glacial, and inter-glacial periods). Their contemporaries (sounds familiar already!) outright rejected these notions.  Charles Darwin did accept their work however. Milanković’s first work on this effort described how the earth’s temperature is based on the sun [A Contribution to the Theory of Mathematical Climate; 1912].

Fast forward through more than 25 years of fascinating mathematics, including creating vectors of each planet and their relationship to each other which resulted in “New Results of the Astronomic Theory of Climate Changes”; 1938.  That was a headache bit of math before computers.  Now NASA/JPL can give you that up to the minute! There have been numerous others who have taken this work and reduced the uncertainty of the calculations.  Even Ms. Lisiecki’s geology work referenced above relied on earlier concepts but expanded the investigation and analysis of the Spectral Mapping project (mentioned above). 

More next time specifically on temperature and CO2 and how to assess honestly.

Bruce Sanders The Greenhouse blocks heat from escaping through convection,  aided by the glass storing solar radiation within the framework. @Arileath The greenhouse does not heat up because there is CO2 kin the air.  It could be Helium and the greenhouse would heat up the same.

Bruce Sanders 
The solar radiation pass through the greenhouse and traps thermal energy inside emitted by the plants inside 
Solar radiation falls on earth (ie plants grown in the greenhouse) and gasses(like the glass in green houses) does not allow the heat to escape 

The gasses are called greenhouse since they absorb infrared light as the molecules change their symmetry when light falls upon them (Infrared active molecules)

Now they both block heat from escaping in different ways, as the greenhouse blocks convection,  the thickening atmosphere keeps the planet warm by preventing wavelengths of infrared radiation from escaping, but the metaphor is similar in principle and commonly used for familiarity with wider audiences.
@Arileath A greenhouse does not work that way.

Bruce Sanders A thickening layer of C02 traps heat and stops it from escaping into space. It’s why it’s called the greenhouse effect. More heat is stored while less and less escapes into space.

This form of climate change is separate from the natural occurrences that contribute to changing temperatures such as the Milankovitch cycles and  S.A.M.
Overall in the long term it will contribute to higher temperatures and we have seen this in places like Scotland that has seen record breaking temperatures. However these rates are not static and climate change isn’t a singular consequence. The polar vortex is an example of this. Sea currents are also a major factor that complicate the immediate effects of human caused climate change

Volcanoes only release around 3% of the CO2 humans release each year, and it was already in the carbon cycle. Natural processes in general definitely does produce more carbon than humans, but this didn't change the environment because natural processes also absorb as much carbon as it released. We tipped this equilibrium by cutting down forests for farmland, and mining fossil fuels to use in machines and power plants. The evidence is clear as the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere continues to increase. Just saying "most CO2 is natural" doesn't change the fact that CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere is rising currently. It's time to stop.

@J P I see, just a wall of text.
A one degree change throughout the ENTIRE WORLD when there are no major world events is a big deal, because it hints that humans are doing something that is warming the Earth. While there are events that have lowered world temperatures by 3-5 degrees, usually by a big volcanic eruption, yes, humans have survived them, but the disasters still caused mass famine and starvation. The 1 degree increase in global temperature is *very* unlikely to be caused by natural events, but rather that we are disrupting the carbon cycle by producing way too much carbon dioxide and simultaneously destroying areas that can re-absorb it. (in fact, the ocean ecosystems are extremely stressed by human activity, whether intentional or not. Garbage and pollution may be a localized problem at first, but the ocean currents take them all over the world.) If you're talking about history, of course there is no "limit" for carbon absorption, as in how much carbon the Earth could potentially absorb. However, the amount that we are releasing is definitely way over the limit as in "how much carbon the planet could absorb from the mess we're making" and since parts/million CO2 are continuing to rise on a global scale, this is evidence that we are past that limit.

@J P carbon sinking: the problem is, at the rate it is now, we are stressing the ecosystems and events like ocean acidification may warn us that the natural carbon absorbing systems on this planet are reaching their limits. Saying "human activity release of CO2 pales in comparison to natural release" is only being ignorant. For one, not only are we pumping carbon into our atmospheres like crazy, we are also removing a large amount of natural carbon absorbers, which will certainly tip the balance, and while I am aware that local events and global temperature increase are different things, the thing is that the planet, on average, has shown a warming of about 1 degree celcius since 1950. Bernie or Warren would be a tepid social democrat in Europe or Latin America. Neolibs like to exploit identity politics (which do have some valid concerns) to distract from class consciousness, imo.
I think properly identifying your political tendency, and properly placing yourself relative to others on the political spectrum is important so you have a clear idea of what you actually want out of politics. You don't need to put yourself in a box, but realize that what you call yourself will affect other's perceptions and potentially distance you from those you agree with (or keep you from distancing yourself from those you disagree with!).

Here is the argument: developing the technologies to become more environmentally friendly is expensive. That cost must be passed onto the customer. This makes a company selling that product not competitive with other companies selling the same product who do not invest in those technologies. 


Example: USA steel company smelts steel. They invest 1 billion dollars into a solar plant to power their smelters. this raises the cost of their steel from $1 per pound to $1.50 per pound. China steel company doesn't invest in green energy and just uses coal power plants to power their smelters. China steel company sells their steel for $1 per pound just like USA steel company did. When a customer comes and says "I need 1000 pounds of steel" they see that to buy from USA steel would be $1500.00 and to buy from China steel would be $1000.00 for the same product. The consensus myth is the result of two very flawed studies. One was soliciting replies from a mailing list of around 3,000 people (most of whom were not climate scientists). 
In the other, the IPCC looked at an arbitrary sample of research papers to see who disagreed with their narrative. Those who disagreed were put in the disagree pile, those who agreed were put in the agree pile. And those who were silent on the IPCC's narrative (which made up more than 90% of studies) were arbitrarily added to the agree pile. This is an obvious and outrageous case of academic fraud.
You should become better informed before you talk down with that air of condescension to those who disagree with your poorly informed views. Some of us have done serious investigation of this topic rather than simply regurgitating what we are told on that juvenile IFL Science facebook page.

​@HerebyOrdinary , sure. The review of studies relates to a review done by Oreskes (not a scientist) in 2004. Subsequent reviews critical of hers discovered that she had simply lumped in studies as 'agree with IPCC', when they offered no opinion one way or the other. This is either academic fraud /gross incompetence. Source: https://friendsofscience.org/assets/documents/97_Consensus_Myth.pdf

If you're more of an audio/visual person, check out James Corbett's channel here on youtube where you will encounter other incidents of academic malpractice by the IPCC related to the generation of the mythical '97%' 'consensus' myth. In particular I recommend this video he did with IPCC insider Donna Laframbois: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOyBfihjQvI
