WE ARE NOT TO BLAME! According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years. That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago, which coincides with the Medieval Warm Period (950-1250 CE). World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle. What we may need are commercial solutions that will aid in the survival of the human race throughout the coming centuries. The following is the source information for this comment:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

Here's the problem with this. He keeps referring to his position as a narrative (n: a spoken or written account of connected events; a story). Let's not create stories about climate change. Let's not attack the billionaires that buried the stories to save their pockets. Let's not try to pin the belief or denial on a group of individuals. Let's look at the data and the science behind it and determine through the scientific method who's to blame and what the facts are.


I do not deny that the climate is changing. I cannot deny that the world is getting warmer, the facts show it. I do, however, believe the cause is not squarely on the shoulders of mankind. I do not deny that we are terrible to our planet, but I also do not believe that our factories and CO2 emissions can have the effect that the climate change people say it is having. When a burp from a volcano belches out more CO2 in a single event than mankind and factories belch out over multiple years, I don't believe we're solely to blame. I like facts. 


For instance, out of all the greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere, only 3.62% is CO2. And out of that 3.62% of greenhouse gasses that are CO2, only 3.4% of that is caused by humans. (source: http://burtrutan.com/downloads/EngrCritiqueCAGW-v4o3.pdf)


Remember that correlation does not imply causation. The industrial revolution may coincide with our measurements of the climate change, but that could be because it was due to the technology that we got better at recording data. The world is getting hotter, by temperature readings across the planet. However, MANY of those temperature systems are built in cities and at airports; places paved and notorious for heat. With the bias for recording temperatures in developed areas, it skews our data. Especially when NASA reported in 2014 that the Antarctic sea ice reached a new record maximum. (source: https://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/antarctic-sea-ice-reaches-new-record-maximum). 



How could the ice sheet reach a new record maximum if the planet is getting warmer due to human involvement in the middle of our climate catastrophe? because our readings are skewed by being taken where streets are paved and jet exhaust heats up the tarmac? I'll say it again: Correlation does not imply causation. I do not deny that the climate is changing, I do deny that we are the cause.


Finally, if humans are to blame for climate change, how come other planets are going through climate change as well? Mars is getting hotter, is our impact on earth affecting the weather on mars? (source: https://www.space.com/33001-mars-ice-age-ending-now.html).


In conclusion, the facts show that climate change is real, but the facts do not support the position that humans are to blame.

In fact it is so complex, people (including climate scientists) cannot figure out what the hell is going on. To make a statement like "extra co2 will lead to runaway greenhouse effect" or "the sunspot activity is showing a new ice age is coming", based on the knowledge we have, is just guessing it with a lot of confidence.

I check the satalite global temperature charts every 2/3 weeks. The temperature has been declining for the last 2 years from the last heat spike in 2016. Most "deniers" think this will continue for another 3 to 6 years, then we will get a matching heat spike to the 2016 spike or maybe a bit lower. 

In this summer(2019), this declining was looking like it stopped and it was going up again. This continued for 3 months in sequence till a heat simular to 2015 (0,2 degree under 2016) was reached. At this time, I was actually worried I might be wrong and that "the pause" was actually true. But it turned out to be a mini-spike, and the temperature went down again to the level it was previously on. " So, I'm still a denier. "

This shows the tolerances we are working with, it is nitpicking with numbers. Decimal numbers of parts-per-million and temperature averages within a degree (all well within error margins).

OK guys, look... I consider myself a conservative for most things in life. A moderate conservative, for that matter. I do agree that climate change is a top priority in our society. However this video missed some MAJOR points. Most people who deny climate change, ALSO have scientists behind them... with lots of studies. If you want to convince someone climate change is real, have a plan on why these other studies are either not accurate or plain wrong (DON'T call the other person a liar or insult them, that'll just make them look better).
Second, stop associating "social justice" with climate change. Even if they are related, people have already created a lot of antibodies against "SJWs" and anything related. Keep focused on the issue. Making the climate better for everyone is in everyone's interest. There's no denying that. But some people think we are going through some natural cycle and scientists are doing all of this "for money". This is not correct. 
Lastly, when discussing these issues with someone who thinks differently than you, don't just assume they are evil or a bad person. Most likely they are not. Just try to be empathic and try to see their viewpoint from their angle.

In fact, only 0.027% of the accepted studies (those who have passed peer review) show no warming at all, no matter how many scientists there are behind, the evidence does not have to be addressed (unless you really want to dive deep)

Also you can't propose people throw aside their views and follow "scientific consensus" when you refuse to throw aside your views and follow "economic consensus" on most of your economic views.  FYI among economists (who have worked closely with climate scientists) it's highly agreed upon that a Carbon Tax would go a long way to addressing the issue without destroying our economy or too badly hurting the poor in other countries; who frankly have much bigger problems to worry about right now like not dying from disease or malnutrition.  And speaking of it's insane to me you don't dedicate the same amount of time to resource depletion as you do to Global Warming when it's a FAR more important environmental issue.  And for the record, the great majority of Americans agree that Global Warming is real and has been accelerated by humans; the debate is over what / how much we should do to fight it.  So please stop talking down to those more pragmatic people like they don't understand.  Stop with the alarmism or nitpicked sources; just persuade them with solid simple objective data showing that spending money now to fight climate change is far more cost effective then spending it later trying to clean it up. I have found it helpful to speak about basic values or fundamental beliefs in discussions with climate change deniers where the "problem" lies in the persons ideological standpoint. For example, it is possible that the climate change denier you describe (individualist,  skeptical to governments) more often than not, has the individuals own freedom as basic value or fundamental belief. In this case argue agains why not saving the climate and preventing climate change will go agains their basic value or fundamental belief. Example, the rise of sea level will render parts of e.g. Florida, like the Keys, uninhabitable since the land will be under water. This will force people to move away from their homes which therefor goes against their right to live wherever they like. This mean that the individuals own right to freedom has been limited as a consequence of climate change. 


But you never know:/ The example is perhaps not the best but it shows the principle of the method which I learned at a climate ethics course.

In an article, the people in Florida Keys attributed the sea level rise to the bridge which was changed at the time (renovation or extension, I don't remember). The argument was that the pylons were somehow redirecting the flow. In this case, it's the internal struggle with two options where one is kind of vague and in of the "out of my control" category while the other option seems much clearer, closer, easier to control.

Instead you moved the goal post and now said that you still wouldn't stop eating meat, even though you agree that better feed isn't in use yet and that the current one is bad, suggesting your position for continuing eating meat was never related to better feeding options. 

Anyway, so now the new argument is that meat is cheap, sustainable and healthy in moderation.

Cheap: I would say again, it's only cheap because of all the incentives and externalities which makes it only artificially cheap. Also all whole food (not processed) plant based protein is even cheaper than meat, so if cheap is an important criteria for you you should go with plant based protein sources. 

Sustainable: the United Nations IPCC, FAO and Oxford disagrees with you. Can you show some equally compelling or higher evidences that suggest the contrary? 

Healthy: in moderation anything can be discarded as not harmful. Depends on what degree of moderation. Anyway, plant foods are healthier as not only they are not associated with an increase of our biggest killers like heart disease, diabetes and some forms of cancer but they are even associated with a decrease or reversal of such problems. So if you are concerned about health you should be following a whole foods plant based diet as well. 

How does your understanding of what your body needs stops you from adopting plants as your primary source of protein? The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics which is the largest nutrition association in the world with more than 100.000 professionals has released a peer reviewed statement backed by 117 studies saying that a well planned vegan diet is not only ideal for all stages of life, including children, pregnancy, athletes, old age, etc, but it's even advantageous in regards to our biggest killer diseases. I hope you aren't presenting anecdotal evidences to counter hundreds of scientific studies... If you do have high order scientific studies to support you position please let me know. Also if you can see meats like impossible meat becoming your primary source just keep in mind that those are made from plants, so saying you won't adopt plant based protein sources because you understand how your body works but at the same time saying you could adopt impossible meat as your primary protein source is contradictory. 

Regarding the family of 5 in the food desert, is that the situation you are in? If it's not, then, again, you can't appeal to it in order justify not changing yourself. If it is, even in food deserts you can find canned beans, rice, potatoes and frozen vegetables cheaply. If you were in an area where nobody supplied those due to not being economically viable then that would also be the case for fast food and in that case you wouldn't really have anything to eat leaving no other choice than to move to another place.

Yes, I admit that in a video like this he wouldn't have been able to make an exhaustive list and touch on every single contributor. I just find it odd that if we consider that there are two major sources, both very bad environmentally speaking, with some reports even mentioning aprox 50/50 in terms of contribution, but then, one of the issues (energy) is very hard to solve, will involve immense changes in infrastructure, personal buying power and which will take a lot of time to achieve, and then the other (animal agriculture) would solve a massive ethical conundrum, would contribute to the improvement of the general health of the population and that basically everybody can start doing it this very evening, it seems to me that it would have so much of a larger impact to focus on the second one that it should be the main one every video should be talking about. I think we should attack every angle of this problem, but with only ~10 years to make a significant difference we should focus on the easiest and most impactful thing each one of us could do, and sadly I don't see myself having the money to buy an electric car any time soon, only to have to charge it using energy still generated in a dirty way. Beans and rice are really cheap though =) Sorry for the long winded response.

If i had a way to check the accuracy of data and it showed that its actually the case i would change my opinion. I fundamentally believe in the right i have to change my opinion, if not there’s not much any critical thinking skills i have is doing for me or will do for in the future. However that would be the case if i was a climate expert, since i am not i have to rely on experts and aggregation of data by other parties to give me a degree of certainty in my opinions. The problem is that given the uncertainty of my own lack of not being an expert and the % chance of experts themselves being wrong for one reason or the other i could question their motives but then i would be left to be a cynic who just is against any and all ideas. I have to stop somewhere and given that my compass in things that i dont know is guided by other authorities i have to accept their view for now.  So to recapitulate the answer to the first question, since i have no way of arriving at that scenario you point out (not being an expert) i have to run the risk and believe in the statistical unlikelihood that the majority of scientific papers and knowledge aggregators are not intellectually dishonest. This comes with the constant risk of me being constantly duped by this large group.

For the second question, yes and it regards mostly the popularization of important philosophical and scientific ideas, such as nihilism, evolution, socialism ect. This is more a readjustment based on primary txt (but nevertheless a considerable shift in perspective). 

Third question. Yes, people will lie for financial gain, but that again goes both ways and using it as compass simply leaves us having no certainty any which way on any topic unless we dedicate our life to becoming an expert in it. Given that its a minus applied to both sides of any equation it still leaves preponderance of opinion as a guiding factor for me, and atm its with climate change.

by the way... about taxes... Sweden has really high taxes. I started to discuss this with an American friend... Because swedes pay crazy amounts of taxes if you look at the raw numbers. But at the same time we get so many things for free.... free education, child care, dental, free common educational grants (for living expenses), healthcare, unemployment funding, retirement etc. When running down the numbers we realized that common 2nd class citizens actually had better lives in Sweden, and although their "pocket money" was less after wage than average 2nd class American. Swedes could actually spend them more casually without worrying about insurance costs, saving for ours kids education, retirement plans etc. (or just the worry about loosing our jobs... I will receive 80% of my pay for at least 9 months, after that it's down to roughly 50%, which is still enough for decent living), we also get 6 weeks paid vacation + extra paid because it's nice during vacation. If you live in a well functioning country, taxes isn't necessarily bad. and tbh it actually saves me from a lot of worry and headache. I'm not saying this to be provocative or upset anybody... just sharing my experience, from another place in the world. :)

Well, we would actually do pretty good if people consumed only what they needed to live a comfortable life (without all the excesses). But politics would never tackle consumption due to how our economical system work. Even in a socialist country like Sweden (where I am from) the green party cannot tackle that question. The state gets a cashback of 25% of what every Swede consume (in the form of taxes).... making the national economy safe, stable and with a working well fare system... I mean, we could live differently, live in communities, share items over several households. Does every house need their own power tools? washing machine? lawnmower? home cinema etc? or could we share those items over several households and in common spaces? You could access the exact same luxury you are used to,  while greatly reduce our need of consumption, and therefore our footprint, and at the same time add a sense of belonging to the community we live in. I don't say this is how everybody should live, I'm just saying that there are ways to downsize our impact on this world, but it requires a lot of rethinking. both socially, culturally, collectively, politically and economically. One solution is not right for every country. And I know that I will probably see things a lot differently than someone from the US. :)

Okay, so you open for a rather interesting discussion at the end, I hope this doesn't just get drowned out by the rest of the comments.

From a certain economic point of view, climate change is not best solved by government intervention. It's not (necessarily) that they genuinely disbelieve in science, but that they distrust the effects of large government action. The primary focus is the inefficiency of bureaucracies.
So, one has to imagine a scenario where an individualistic, market-driven solution to climate change is presented. A general problem with this is that alternative energy sources are usually less efficient. This is where I introduce the topic of nuclear energy.

In a way, my strongest argument when faced with someone of a more right-leaning political orientation is the my belief that public perception of nuclear energy harms economic growth, which is of course common ground with individualistic, market-oriented thinkers. If you don't agree with me on the question of nuclear power, there are similar issues, such as hydro-electric dams. These dams suffer the same public perception issues, and thus government regulation issues, as nuclear power, and serve as an effective tool to combat climate change. 

Essentially the advice I'm giving is to show that some of the possible solutions may align with their views, even if you might politically oppose those solutions.

There really is a crisis here. It's the lack of ability to accept information that contradicts preconceived beliefs. In terms of Climate Change science, even scientists are vulnerable to this. If someone comes up to you with information that essentially invalidates all your life's work and every degree you've handed out as a professor, you tend to reject it out right even if that information is solid and grounded in facts. The biggest problem with consensus science is that it  makes it possible for vast number of scientists to fall victim to the same underlying flaws of that consensus, while simultaneously giving the hypothesis as a whole a sense of truth without actually being true. 'All these scientists say it's true, so it must be.' right? This isn't logistical thinking at all. History proves that it only takes one person to get something right, and it is often the majority who find themselves on the side of denial. This is why Galileo had such a hard time convincing everyone the world was round and not flat despite him having all the evidence he needed in his notes and in the view of his telescope. They had a consensus that they refused to let go of until the evidence was just to overwhelming. 
This time we find ourselves in that same situation, only now it's about how climate changes. That facts are that we do need to regulate emissions and clean the environment. The facts are also that consensus scientists have fallen victim to a fatal flaw in their work that effectively makes every paper, book, study, and model void and invalid because they all share the same foundation. There is more on this here if you want to better understand our climate and the situation we really face as a species:

Copied from me answering someone how "CO2 causes climate change?"

Heat radiates from the sun, which warms the earth. both CO2 and the Earth's surface reflect that radiation back into space, absorbing a little bit whenever it reflects, which we feel as heat. If you imagine the sun's radiation as 100 rays of light at 100% power, and every time they reflect they lose one tenth their power (really simplifying it here), if we had no CO2 in the atmosphere it'd reflect all off the surface once and we'd absorb 10% of the radiation of all 100 rays and as heat and the other 90% of all 100 rays would bounce back into space. If the earth was half covered in CO2, 50 rays would bounce back into space immediately and the other 50 would bounce back off the surface. The heating comes because of the 50 that hit the earth, only 25 will bounce back into space, the other 25 will hit the CO2 again, bouncing back to earth, then 12.5 into space and 12.5 on the CO2, etc., and by the end both the surface and the CO2 have absorbed much of the ray's energy because they keep bouncing back and forth trapped within our atmosphere. It's like that old brick breaker game, if you trap the ball between layers of bricks, you destroy a lot more, except instead of bricks it's CO2 and the Surface and instead of the ball it's radiation.


please tell me if i got something wrong i dont wanna spread innacurate information

@Andreas Egeland you're right, i forgot sunlight also is refracted by the earth's surface into a different wavelength, so the beams that pass by the CO2 the first time aren't the same type that are absorbed on the bounce back, and that refraction is what makes them more susceptible to being absorbed and holding onto the heat (Again i'm only like 90% sure on this)

I think it's mostly right, but maybe a bit unclear.
The heating comes because the heat bounces off the earth, then "heats up" the CO2, which then shines the heat in a random direction, so that roughly half of it going back to earth. This loop keeps happening for a few times, like you explain.
If you maybe said something wrong, it's that if half the Earth was covered by CO2, then it would likely still reflect the same amount of light in the first step, it would just hold on to the heat better. So what's happening is that CO2 absorbs heat, but not sunlight.

I have found when talking to climate deniers going for the flooding in coastal areas and on the Mississippi tends to be an in.  It's harder to deny that your Grandpa had a farm on the river and now every other year it is filled with water to the point you have to ask for money from the federal government.  Pointing out that a higher levee isn't actually helping because the river just goes higher the next year is a pretty obvious thing. That said I grew up 10 miles from the Mississippi river it's a lot easier to convince people affected than the guy in an office building in  NYC!

I think it's also based somewhat on subconscious fear of losing lifestyle. My major climate denier has spent 30+ years working on finding and tapping oil fields safely. I will never convince him that climate is real because his job is part of him right now and it would hurt his self image to think that what he did had a bad impact on the world. Especially since he wants to leave a good impact when he dies and most of his impact has been growing our oil supply.

Here are my thoughts:
-The Planet will always be fine, many mass extinction events are linked to volcanic eruptions or other events that completely messed with the atmosphere/oceans. Life recovers as always, just not in the form that existed (well for the most part, some species do survive). So "Save the planet" is meaningless in my eyes as these events will happen over and over again regardless of our actions, perhaps we can divert an asteroid, but we can't do anything about the killing potential of our planet's active core. The catchphrase should be "Save our asses", now THAT compels me.
-About that relevant catchphrase, I also think humanity naturaly progresses towards self-preservation and more ecological ways of living. Advanced societies do it the most, so 1st world countries are to blame the least, while developing countries do the most damage. We'll still go through a period of a couple hundred years where China and India will cause the vast majority of polution and after them African and other growing Asian countries will jump on the mass polution train as they transition into advanced societies where priorities shift from survival and growth at all costs into being able (economically free enough) to be mindful of the environment.

Well, from my own experience, a lot of people think that science tells us that human activity is not responsible for the climate change. They usually talks about "natural cycles", sun activity, and so on.
They even have articles (pseudo-scientific articles) to "prove" their point. The only way to convince those people, imo, is to demonstrate them, one data point at a time, how their source of information twists the facts or hides important informations. Those peope are like you and me: they don't like being lied to.
It's generally a long work, not fun to do, and sometimes you have to work hard on yourself not to loose your temper when they start calling you names or acting smug.

Also, we definitively need to learn how to have an epistemic interview. Have a look at the work of Anthony Magnabosco. Listen, ask questions, let them take their time to think. Most of times, your goal shouldn't be to convince people, but just to shatter a bit their beliefs, bring them a bit of doubt and the tools to start rethinking their point of view. And then, let them do the rest of the work themselves. And try to be nice. Don't start this if you won't be to able stay nice, calm and patient.

Oh, and never start that kind of conversation in public. One to one "debate" is better, because nobody will feel judged by others, you won't feel the need to show the "audience" that you're right. So you both will be less inclined to be on the defensive.

The first thing to do in science, including social science, is to define your terms. Not 'know your audience' so you can do effective PR, but know your subject so you're not making dishonest propaganda with your PR. 'Climate change denier' is undefined, but used for PR to defame. Its usage includes literally opposite things, from people who deny there is global warming, all the way over to people who think it is real and urgent, who oppose the policies of what is effectively the officially sanctioned green movement, which that movement itself declares are ineffective and insufficient, and support instead the only serious measures -- geoengineering and nuclear energy - to combat global warming. And everything in-between, which runs a vast range, including real scientists who try to clarify the known facts and the state of science and predictive probabilities about global warming and correct the simplistic PR versions that are being massively broadcast on that subject.

As, Kropotkine said in the Spirit of Revolt:
"The need for a new way of life becomes apparent. The traditional code of morals, which governs most people in their daily life, no longer seems sufficient. What formerly seemed 'just' is now felt to be a crying injustice. Yesterday's morality is recognised today as revolting immorality..."
And that's the point. The morals of Climate Deniers is based, as you pointed out, on individualism, profit above all, uncontrolled free market and thus, uncontrolled exploitation of resources, continuous growth... Yes, it's the capitalistic values, and those values are failing us, we realise more and more how unsustainable they are! We need a new set of values and morality. Values of collaboration, resilience, care, regeneration... I do not want to pretend that fighting climate change can be done with this old set of values and morality! In the buzzwords you showed to convince republicans there are "Energy Freedom, Competition, National Security...". Those aren't good values. They are opposite to a world of collaboration between countries and individuals, and using them won't fix climate change, it won't solve the deeper causes of it, and at best, will just postpone some its consequences...
We have a great chance today of entering a new era for humanity, and more and more people are convinced of that. People are ready to relinquish their ego, to fight for a real political life, where politic is at the hand of citizens and isn't just statecraft as it is now, the privileges of some is viewed as immoral more and more, people want a true Climate, Ecological and Social Justice to finally happen. That is to add to the universal declaration of human's rights something like "Everybody, everywhere and everywhen, have the same right to access the natural wealth"!
Yes, *Yesterday's morality is recognised today as revolting immorality* and we shouldn't compromise our values to please some climate deniers that have no future anyway!

Explain to me scientifically why CO2 causes global warming. Convince me that all insects in the world do not emit more CO2 on the planet than all cars combined. Tell me why the temperature of the planet does not change since 1998? Explain to me scientifically why to consider a medium temperature as a measure when the temperatures inside the planet vary between -80C and 70C? Explain to me why every scientist who denies global climate warming have their research funds cancelled? Explain to me scientifically all the temperatures variances inside planet earth during the last 4,5 billion years? Explain to me scientifically what would happen with life on earth without CO2 in the atmosphere? Explain to me scientifically the influence of the Sun in the temperatures of our planet and also explain the periods the Sun is more active and less active? Convince me that only 1 Vulcan eruption can release more CO2 in the atmosphere than all industrial activities of a year? If you explain all these things to me logically maybe I can believe that your video is sincere and you believe in all this bullshit about global warming.

1. Heat radiates from the sun, which warms the earth. both CO2 and the Earth's surface reflect that radiation back into space, absorbing a little bit whenever it reflects, which we feel as heat. If you imagine the sun's radiation as 100 rays of light at 100% power, and every time they reflect they lose one tenth their power (really simplifying it here), if we had no CO2 in the atmosphere it'd reflect all off the surface once and we'd absorb 10% of the radiation of all 100 rays and as heat and the other 90% of all 100 rays would bounce back into space. If the earth was half covered in CO2, 50 rays would bounce back into space immediately and the other 50 would bounce back off the surface. The heating comes because of the 50 that hit the earth, only 25 will bounce back into space, the other 25 will hit the CO2 again, bouncing back to earth, then 12.5 into space and 12.5 on the CO2, etc., and by the end both the surface and the CO2 have absorbed much of the ray's energy because they keep bouncing back and forth trapped within our atmosphere. It's like that old brick breaker game, if you trap the ball between layers of bricks, you destroy a lot more, except instead of bricks it's CO2 and the Surface and instead of the ball it's radiation.
2. You're right, insects do produce more than all cars combined, however, the amount of carbon which is reabsorbed into the carbon cycle has been regulated by eons of natural processes, and the amount output by all insects, animals, etc. has been matched by the earth reabsorbing it; humans have output more than the earth can reabsorb, i.e. if all animals output 750 gigatons of CO2, and the earth absorbed 750 gigatons, it maintains balance, but imagine humans then output an additional 25 gigatons, not there's more than the earth can handle, and there's the crisis.
3. It has, but even if it hadn't such a short time period wouldn't paint the bigger picture, which is we've had an uptick of global temperature increases since the industrial revolution.
4. Because it's easier that way to explain to laymen and policy makers one single temperature than hundreds of individual climates. The medium temperature is a shorthand.
5. Because the overwhelming scientific consensus supports the existence of human-influenced climate change, so why would we continue to support work which is demonstrably wrong?
6. The earth naturally goes through cycles of heating and cooling. we are currently on a uptrend towards heating, as predicted from ancient records, but we're at higher temperatures than expected.
7. We'd die... what is this question no one's saying to get rid of CO2???
8. Refer to no.1, as well, the sun is a giant ball of electrically-charged hot gas, and since they move around in a plasma, they go through a natural 11year cycle of switching the northern and southern magnetic poles (like that video of the astronaut spinning a t-handle in zero gravity, it flips back and forth). During these flips, solar activity increases. When it's not flipping, it's comparatively less active.
9. They don't, though. Volcanic eruptions in a year can produce up to 300million tonnes of CO2, but fossil fuel emissions produce somewhere around 20BILLION tonnes of CO2. Volcanoes *can* have a greater effect, though this is because of the aerosols released into the air which trap radiation (see no.1)

It would be interesting to know what happened in the Arctic during the 10,800 BCE abrupt climate change. We know there were two ice sheets - smaller Cordilleran and bigger Laurentide on North America. The Laurentide perhaps 3 - 4 km thick at some places. 

There was a paper published in Feb 2018 in The Journal of Geology about extraordinary biomass burning around 10,800 BCE. It is fascinating.

Adjusted quote: "Around 10,800 BCE, likely within the span of 21 years between 10,818 BCE and 10,797 BCE, ∼9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ∼10 million km2 (area as big as the US), burned. The concentrations of soot, used to estimate the global amount of biomass burned, suggest that wildfires around 10,800 BCE consumed considerably more biomass than during the K-Pg extinction event."

If interested the links are https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695703?journalCode=jg for part 1 and https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695704 for part 2. 

It would be interesting to calculate how much CO2 must have been released when ∼9% of world terrestrial biomass on ∼10 million km2 burned. The wildfires on 70,000 km² in Australia this year are estimated to release about 900 million tons of CO2, which equals to double the country's total yearly fossil fuel emissions."

Perhaps CO2 released by burning of ∼9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ∼10 million km2 might have contributed to melting of Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets? At present CO2 melts ice in Arctic, Greenlad, Antarctica so we can assume it should have been melting ice also around 10,800 BCE as well. 

There is a puzzling energy paradox. Melting of ice sheets happened during very cold period, so it should not have happened.

What mechanisms or combination of might have caused rapid melting of several kilometres thick ice sheets?

One simple physics principle is that the weight of several millions cubic kilometres of ice pushes the continent down. Heavy ice depresses the surface, at times pushing it below sea level, making the ice sheets to get in contact with warmer ocean, causing the ice sheets to retreat and stabilizing the system. Destabilize the system enough with a powerful external factor and things start moving quickly. 

Recent scientific papers start to provide more and more evidence that an external fast acting factor was in effect around 10,800 BCE. 

The paper published in March 2020 in Nature provides evidence of cosmic impact at Syria, coeval with impacts that deposited high-temperature meltglass, melted microspherules, and/or platinum at >50 sites on four continents around 10,800 BCE. Link to the article https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w

Impact on several kilometres thick ice sheet in Canada would not have left a permanent crater imprinted in the ground but more likely a depression filled with water which today would be in the form of a lake. 

There are several candidates for comet fragments impacts on ice sheet in Canada around 10,800 BCE. One of them possibly in Great Lakes area, perhaps the Saginaw Bay, Michigan // Lake Nippon // Manicouagan Reservoir // Gulf of Saint Lawrence // 

It is suggested it started in direction from Western coast to Eastern coast. 

It would be interesting to check the known impact craters in the world for a possible "string impacts. Just a few candidates - Rochechouart crater in France, Saint Martin crater in Manitoba, Obolon crater in Ukraine, Red Wing crater in North Dakota. If there is any researcher or enthusiast out there able to get some funding go for it.:-)

If you have not seen a string impact video please check the well-known Shoemaker–Levy 9 string impacts on Jupiter in July 1994 on BBC Studios YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgOTcIfU75Y

As mentioned in the March 2020 paper in Nature (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w) there might have been multiple airbursts/impacts across at least four continents. These are proposed to have resulted from a one of a series of short-period, active comets known to break up frequently and to shed dozens to thousands of fragments that are 10 to 1000 m in diameter, each capable of producing catastrophic airburst/impacts. The largest cometary debris clusters are proposed to be capable of causing thousands of airbursts within a span of minutes across one entire hemisphere of Earth. An encounter with such a million-km-wide debris cluster would be thousands of times more probable than a collision with a 100-km-wide comet or a 10-km asteroid.

When invisible radiation dust fell like raindrops on May 1, 1986 in Ukraine, children walked past the reviewing stand, where Soviet leaders usually sat, but now only rows of empty chairs were in sight.

Just a few days earlier on April 26, the Chernobyl nuclear power plant located in Ukraine exploded, releasing nuclear radiation 400 times that of the Hiroshima atomic bomb dropped during World War II. It was one of the most severe catastrophes in human history. Tens of thousands of people were infected with radioactive substances for a long time, and the land was equally contaminated. Chernobyl became a deserted city overnight.

Instead of saving lives, the first thing Soviet officials did was to conceal information. The earliest news about the disaster all came from foreign media outlets. Still, the Soviet Union refused to admit that there was nuclear radiation for fear of unrest among the people. No protective masks were distributed, and books about radiation were removed from libraries. All phone calls to Chernobyl were cut off.

Local officials moved their families out of Ukraine and quickly evacuated their children while keeping the general public in the dark without any protective measures.

The parade in Ukraine went ahead under orders from above. People were told to remove the radiation-contaminated lawn with shovels, without any protective equipment, and were not told why they should do so.

Doctors were not allowed to write “acute radiation syndrome” on medical reports. And water and air were declared safe in that area.

Once you learn more about the history of climate changes on our 4.5 billion year old planet, you’ll stop falling for the lies. And you’ll understand that some of the past changes were far more extreme than what we’re currently seeing.

) On January 9, Libero, a nationally circulated Italian newspaper, reported the findings of an independent tribunal regarding the state-sanctioned killing of prisoners of conscience for organs in China. The newspaper article also strongly condemned the human rights crisis.

The interim judgment by the Independent Tribunal Into Forced Organ Harvesting from Prisoners Of Conscience in China (the China Tribunal) was delivered in London on December 10, 2018.


Italian media outlet Libero published an article about the London tribunal.

The article stated, “After listening to 30 witnesses for three days, from 8 to 10 December, the Chair of the tribunal, Sir Geoffrey Nice, QC, …... concluded: The Tribunal’s members are all certain – unanimously, and sure beyond reasonable doubt – that in China forced organ harvesting from prisoners of conscience has been practiced for a substantial period of time involving a very substantial number of victims."

The final judgment, which is due in spring 2019, promises details and figures. Though it carries no legal authority, it will serve as an evidence-based record that can place pressure on international organizations and raise public awareness.

Libero told its readers, “The Independent Tribunal is an independent public assembly inspired by the International Coalition to End Transplant Abuse in China (ETAC), the world's leading body to deal with the issue. Its constitution was announced in the British Parliament on the initiative of Jim Shannon, a Northern Irish member of the Democratic Unionist Party, president of the Interparliamentary Group for Religious Freedom.”

Unions had to make sacrifices in wage increases and other benefits like child care because healthcare was used as a negotiating tactic. Medicare For All is comprehensive and equal too or better than most union plans. Instead of having to renegotiate their healthcare every time and sacrificing wage increases and other benefits, unions can finally focus on securing wage increases for members. Under Medicare For All, union members have more comprehensive healthcare, that is guaranteed and can't be stripped and used against them when they go on strike. This happened to UAW members when GM took away their healthcare, leaving many members' families helpless. Even under union plans, there are still premiums (which is essentially a private tax), etc. Under Medicare For All, that's all eliminated. Unless you've been living under a rock Medicare For All saves money. "The analysis, conducted by researchers at Yale University, the University of Florida and the University of Maryland, found that transitioning the U.S. to a single-payer health care system would actually save an estimated $450 billion each year, with the average American family seeing about $2,400 in annual savings. The research, which was published Saturday in the medical journal The Lancet, also found that Medicare for all would prevent about 68,000 unnecessary deaths per year." - Newsweek  This isn't the only study that shows this. So, yeah there is no "bankrupting", it's cheaper than the current system and saves money.

​@Zorcon741 He isn't nationalizing healthcare. He is cutting out the middle man which are useless, for-profit health insurance companies. Insurance companies aren't healthcare, they are the middlemen to get access to healthcare. So the "means of production" or in other words "the facilities and resources for producing goods" which would be healthcare, in this case, aren't owned by the public. Medicare For All is a single-payer program. You can choose what hospital you want and what doctor. You actually have more choice, because you don't have to worry about your Doctor being out of network. Medicare For All pays for whatever treatment your Doctor recommends like usual. You also don't have to worry about what happens to your health insurance if you leave your job, get fired, your employer changes your provider if you're a small business if you're self-employed, etc it provides security. Private insurance still exists, but it can only supplement, whatever Medicare 4 All doesn't cover.

Don’t be fooled by these ignorant politicians. They, for the most part, clearly don’t have very strong grasps on environmental science. We cannot just outlaw fossil fuels and expect society to not fall apart. We must first replace fossil fuels in energy production with reliable green energy such as nuclear power. Look at France, 75% of their electricity is nuclear while solar and wind are only about 2-3%. Forget the PCA, we should fix ourselves before even thinking about telling other countries what to do. We tend to jump ahead with things like electric cars but what good are they if the electricity is from fossil fuel power plants? When it comes to mining, we cannot just stop as we need those resources. Warren talked about “sustainable” mining as if that’s a thing (we mine for things that don’t replenish themselves so it is impossible to be sustainable). Instead, we need to make technological advancements like sodium (a very abundant element) ion batteries so we don’t need to mine for nearly as much lithium (a rare and toxic metal). Maybe focus on phasing out coal and oil before natural gas, which can act as a temporary main source of energy until we can reach mostly green. It seems to me most of these people are exaggerating the current state of global warming and using it as an excuse to implement their socialist policies. If the government was less of a regulation monster, private nuclear power plants could become more abundant. If a candidate truly cared about environmental issues, they’d talk about specific solutions, not regurgitated crap about solar and wind power (two very inefficient and destructive energy sources on a big scale). A big problem we face is the disappearing of the Ogallala Auqifer from us taking more water from it than is being replaced but they aren’t talking about that. Biden said cities are experiencing the worst, maybe thats because they are all run by Democrats? Warren kept referring to “colored communities”, isn’t that a little racist instead of calling them “poor”? Don’t believe these clowns, do your own research on environmental science as many people are ignorant on it. Can you (the reader) explain the actual science behind climate change? Define albedo, global warming potential, ozone (good and bad), CFCs, etc. Please watch some informational videos and documentaries so you can teach climate change deniers the real science rather than calling them idiots. For example, telling someone “the poor ice caps are melting and sea levels are rising” doesn’t prove global warming is human caused. That’s is an affect not proof. That proves nothing because without evidence by the scientific reasoning, you could argue that aliens are shining a laser at the poles. Remember that environmentalism isn’t political, it’s about life, all life. Republicans don’t hate nature, in fact more spend more time in it than Democrats I’m sure, they just don’t like big government and socialism.

Hi, 410 ppm represents 0.041 % of the atmosphere, not a 0.41% increase in co2. (also, notice the extra zero/decimal place). That is an increase from 0.028 % of the atmosphere (280 ppm) over approx. 270 years, (1750 - 2020), so an actual increase of 130 ppm, or an extra 0.013% of the atmosphere. 

0.041 % ÷ 0.028 % = a 46 % increase in co2 levels. ( not to be confused with 46 % of the atmosphere ). Add to that, the widely accepted, well known fact that increasing co2 gives diminishing returns. So, for example, a doubling of co2, ( or a 100 % increase in co2 levels ), will only result in approx. 1*C temp rise. So, even at 560 ppm, (2× 280 ppm), or 0.056 % of the atmosphere, temps would rise only 1*C. According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

@Thatguys Son While you are right that green color (chlorophyll) in plants has a pretty high absorptance and low reflectivity (albedo) of a large spectrum of photon wavelengths (besides 500nm to 600nm which contains the green and yellow colors we perceive as shown in figure 5 of https://cnx.org/contents/-CmzvUct@11/The-Light-Dependent-Reactions-of-Photosynthesis ), it only accounts for a few milligrams of a millilitre of biomass as found in https://clu-in.org/download/ert/2030-R00.pdf. So what about the rest of the plant? (Summary of water cycle) Transpiration through the stomata of the leaves of plants cools it down a lot due to water's insanely high latent heat of vaporisation, which transfers loads of heat from plants to the atmosphere. The water vapor then reaches saturation point high up in the troposphere causing condensation which results in the formation of clouds and the vast amounts of energy lost to the surroundings during this stage causes negligible changes in temperature due to the sparseness of air near the tropopause. The radiation, however is released into space as water droplets have very very low transmissivity, so very low amounts of EM waves permeate through. Due to the fact that plants generally have very very high amounts of water (90-95% from https://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/earth/geophysics/h2o5.htm ), and since it has extremely high specific heat capacity of 4180J/Kkg, it requires a huge amount of heat to heat it up. Water has high absorptance, yet the vast majority of radiation only results in negligible temperature increases and microwave radiation, despite being one of the best frequency to heat water, requires a huge amount of energy flux density, of up to 0.1 - 0.2 W/cm^2 for significant heat gain over a reasonable amount of time. Consider other factors,  and also ask yourself why is greenery described as a heat sink?

@Darth Bane These guys are largely persistent trolls. They love stating the % concentration of CO2 as a strawman and then argue how can a small number be so bad? But it's a meaningless ratio where you divide a non precipitous GHG by the sum of O2, Nitrogen, and a little bit of Argon, none of which are GHG's. You may just as well divide by the number of stars in the sky or grains of sand at the beach. It's pointless, but they love the number. Comparing CO2 concentration to H20 is also a red herring because H20 is precipitous, it reaches a saturation point and then falls as rain. CO2 is only removed by organic processes, dissolving in sea water (leading to acidification of the surface skin), and chemically through the weathering of rocks. An average ICE car that gets 20 miles per gallon of gas produces about 1 lb of CO2 per year, drive it 12,000 miles per year and you just put 6 tons of CO2 into the atmosphere, some of which will remain for hundreds of thousands of years (the chart has a very long flat tail, after the biosphere sinks and ocean sinks stabilize the remainder is consumed from weathering rocks, which takes a looooong time). H20 is an important GHG, but the relationship between CO2 and H20 is best described as CO2 as being the volume control, the more CO2 the warmer the air gets & the more moisture it can hold so the warmer it gets. These knuckleheads here don't care to learn, they just like to stir the pot. I like to kick sand in their face. I used to be polite until I realized the willful ignorance I was up against.

Steve Spam Of course the Earth has been hotter than it is now in the last 500 million years. 500 million years ago, the first dinosaurs didn’t even exist yet. But in the past, the climate would usually change at a rate that was slow enough for species to adapt and survive. It’s one of the factors that caused evolution. But if the climate changes too quickly, it could lead to major disasters. One example that’s far more extreme than even what we’ve been dealing with so far probably happened 66 million years ago, according to an article by National Geographic. A lot of people accept the possibility that the dinosaurs were killed by one of the many rocks floating in space, but most fictional depictions I’ve seen show the impact, as if that’s what killed all the dinosaurs and somehow left the smaller animals untouched. In reality, if it really was a meteor impact, it was probably all of the ash and debris filling the sky and blocking out the sun that killed the big planets, starving the big herbivores, and indirectly starving the big carnivores. That ended once the ash settled, so the small creatures feasting on the corpses of giants survived and evolved into the animals we know today. All of that happened over the course of tens of millions of years, so to say that the Earth was hotter hundreds of millions of years ago doesn’t say much.

Temperature profile of Cities/Towns: Growing Thermal islands and weather stations.
http://www.mdpi.com/2413-8851/1/1/3
https://www.gislounge.com/urban-heat-island-analysis/
As cities expand the Weather stations gets effected by the error known as Urban heat (well known to early scientists in the late 1800s). 
The Early scientists who were studying the weather, knew about these urban thermal islands and made sure that the early basic weather stations were upwind (with prevailing winds) in the rural areas from the cities. They also took note of wind direction at time of readings. Now if you map the locations of weather stations (and their relocations and other structures including hills etc with wind) and map the encroachment of Urban life around it over time. For example a bird nest attached to a weather station can effect the humidity and Temperature readings giving an offset in error. When occupied the heat rises and when teh reader go to the box the bird flies away. The heat is still been given off while the reader is reading. Also the humidity can be effected as it is evaporating from the bird nest, especially when it is been built. Also the Reader can effect very fine measurement reading by their very presence. Breading down or near the sensor can effect fine tune humidity readers. The heat from the body can cause the temperature reading to rise slightly. Care must be taken by the reader to be down wind of the instruments when taking reading, as a human being is a thermal island and a humidity island.

When you map the development/Economic status over time, you will noticed the rapid development in the 1960's onwards that corresponds with the rising heat. The 1980s drop in heat production with the economic depression. Same with the cooling with the latest great economic recession caused by government bail outs by taxing the people and cuts in spending stopping people from generating heat. Also Look at population growth in line with Thermal heat expenditure and the reduction of family size as people moved into a nuclear family homes and then the next stage, the separation of families (divorce) with Thermal expenditure.  If poor people had more money they burnt more fuel giving off heat. Poor people were often suffered from fuel poverty during economic recession/depressions, hence the lowering of temperature. Now map both together. Middle classes also reduce their heat footprint, which effect the weather stations.

In Thomas Jefferson’s book, Note on the State of Virginia, he argued for the United States to be founded on an agrarian ideology. In the excerpt we read for class today, Jefferson called for an American economy built on agriculture and to “let the work-shops” remain in Europe”. He recognized the need for some domestic industry but believed the vast land of America could be utilized by farming. Alexander Hamilton’s views contradicted Jefferson’s and his views on manufacturing and industry prevailed; consequently, America has progressed into a state of manufacturing rather than an agrarian state. This trend has become increasingly evident over time. Today, less than 2% of Americans farm. “Even though everyone still eats, taking part in the practice of growing food has less direct influence on people’s lives than at any point in our history (Hagenstein et al 3). Thus, we see the prevailing view of Alexander Hamilton as having profound impacts on the American economy and the global environment.

Thomas Jefferson adamantly advocated for the founding of this country to be based on agrarian ideals. Agrarianism supports working on land in ways that can last due to its focus on the interconnectedness of life (Freyfogle xix). Agrarians are sustainable and understand that humans need the Earth, land, and animals for our very subsistence. In the agrarian mindset, the health of humans is dependent in the long run on the well being of the larger land community (Freyfogle xix). Clearly, agrarian views dissent greatly from the views of the majority of modern people, especially those living in urban or suburban settings in the United States. Agrarians “believe that those who buy products are implicated morally in their production, just as those who discard waste items are morally involved in their final end… Producers and sellers, too, are morally responsible for their work, and in ways the market cannot absolve or cleanse when their products are sold”. Of course, one cannot live in a place without altering it, however, agrarians are about harmonizing their relationship and effect on nature, not exploiting it. From these readings, I came to be constantly asking myself the same question, “If Thomas Jefferson’s agrarian ideology prevailed, would we still be in the current state of environmental degradation we are currently in?

Carbon Dioxide is a well understood Greenhouse Gas. Increasing Carbon Dioxide into the atmosphere will, with absolute certainty increase the temperature of the Earth, you can read about it here http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/EnergyBalance/page7.php

Humans are adding an unprecedented amount of Carbon Dioxide into the atmosphere. We know the source of Carbon Dioxide by the isotope ratios. Carbon-13 is a stable isotope of Carbon. Plants do not absorb much Carbon-13 because it takes more energy for them to use. This means that plants have less Carbon-13 than the atmosphere. If we see the percentage of Carbon-13 in the atmosphere falling we know for certain that the source is plant material. Oil and coal are ancient plants we know for certain that burning coal and oil is the source of atmospheric Carbon Dioxide. You can read about it here https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/outreach/isotopes/stable.html

The source of the increased Carbon Dioxide in the atmosphere is not from volcanoes, it is not from the ocean, it is, with certainty, from burning fossil fuels. It will heat up the atmosphere and it's source is humans.

The equator of the sun spins faster than the poles of the sun, this causes it to wind itself up like a top. It periodically releases this pent up energy over time then returns to a more normal state. This causes both short term and long term changes in the amount of energy given off by the sun. To monitor solar radiation we put a satellite into orbit between Earth and the Sun called SOHO  You can look up information about SOHO here https://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov
Because we monitor solar output constantly we know for certain that modern warming is not caused by the sun. While solar output has been declining recently, the temperature has continued to rise. However the sun is responsible for some warming trends in the past.

The Earth is pulled in its orbit by the other planets. They tug on it over time and slightly change its orbit. The Earth's orbit around the sun is not a perfect circle but an ellipse. This change in Earth's orbit causes energy from the sun to hit the planet in different ways over time. This change in how the Earth orbits the sun causes long term changes in Earth's climate. This is called the Millankovitch Cycle. You can read about MIlankovitch Cycles here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles
When the sun heats up the oceans the oceans release carbon dioxide. This carbon dioxide causes a feedback loop where the temperature rises even higher than the Milankovitch Cycle would have alone. Most changes in the climate prior to humans were caused by either changes in solar radiation and the Milankovitch Cycle. Milankovitch Cycles are over long time periods of 22,000 to 400,000 years. We know for certain that the Milankovitch Cycle is not responsible for modern warming. It does not make abrupt changes in climate we have seen in the last 100 years. However Milankovitch Cyles are primarily responsible for changes in the climate in the past.

In addition the ocean is currently absorbing Carbon Dioxide despite the fact that it's warming. You can read about the ocean absorbing Carbon Dioxide here http://pmel.noaa.gov/co2/story/Ocean+Acidification
This has never happened in the entire Quaternary. The ocean has never, in the last 2.5 million years warmed and absorbed Carbon Dioxide at the same time. This is unnatural.

The adverse impact of rising CO2 concentrations on the protein levels in pollen may be playing a role in the global die-off of bee populations by undermining bee nutrition and reproductive success. 

Samuel Myers, a senior research scientist at Harvard’s School of Public Health, has published groundbreaking studies on how rising CO2 levels lower the nutritional quality of foods that we eat, like rice, wheat, and maize, which lose significant amounts of zinc, iron, and protein when grown under higher concentrations of CO2. Plant composition depends on a balance between air, soil, and water. As CO2, the source of carbon for plant growth, proliferates quickly in the atmosphere, soil nutrients — such as nitrogen, iron, and magnesium — remain the same. As a result, plants produce more carbohydrates, but dilute other nutrients.

Fossil fuels are only cheap because of the $500 billion/year subsidy the world pays outside of the price of the fuels from the pollution, national security, health effects, accidents, ocean acidification and climate change they cause.  

Putting a fee on the fuels simply accounts for those negative costs to society, and makes fossil fuels compete on a more equal footing with other energy options.  Returning all the money collected (minus administration costs of a few percent a year) protects our purchasing power, and the economy.  

The Citizens' Climate Lobby proposal is to do this with a steadily increasing fee rather than all at once, so the market can do what you say and provide the solutions over time.  But the market needs the direction to do so, and something like the clear market signal that making Carbon Fee and Dividend a law is necessary to get us out of the current mess we're in.

One of you clowns down here (it's irrelevant which one) says incorrectly (big surprise that is) "if we burn all the world’s recoverable fossil fuels it will still only result in a temperature rise of less than 1.2 per cent". A temperature rise of 1.2% is +3.3 degrees which is 20% more than the most likely increase that is going to occur in 70 years after CO2 reaches 560 ppmv (about +2.8 degrees, that is +2.0 degrees warmer than today) but the largest estimate of the world’s recoverable fossil fuels is 15 times as much CO2 as that and it'll likely last 700 to 1,000 years. That would in theory raise temperature +11.6 degrees warmer than today if the oceans keep taking in ~25% of it and feedbacks remain the same, and that happens to be almost exactly the same as paleoclimate says it was 60,000,000 years ago when India plate finished basjing into Asia and CO2 as ~7,000 ppmv or some such, but permafrost methane is a new wrinkle that wasn't around then so that might push it a bit higher - bottom line is near certainly (very certainly) 10 to 16 degrees warmer than today in 700 to 1,000 years after all of the world’s recoverable fossil fuels have been burned. Obviously, all Greenland ice and most West Antarctic will be gone in 1,000 years for sure plus that big glacier in East Antarctic (it has as much ice as Greenland) with the rest of East Antarctic ice likely melting over the next couple of thousand years, but that's getting so far into the future that it's all up in there from then on.

So lets put you back to bed.

Mars and Venus have the same concentrations of Co2.

Both planets have atmospheric CO2 concentrations around 95%. Earth’s atmosphere has only 0.04% CO2. The density of CO2 in both planet’s atmospheres is much higher than Earth’s atmosphere.
 
Temperatures on Venus average a balmy 467°C, but temperatures on Mars average a nippy −63 °C. Why the big difference?
 

According to the “runaway CO2 greenhouse” theory, both planets should be really hot. Mars is twice as far away from the Sun, so its top of atmosphere receives only 25% of the solar radiation as Venus. But clouds on Venus reflect 75% of the sunlight – so the SW radiation flux at the surface is similar on the two planets.
 
So why is Venus hot and Mars cold? Simple – it is the atmospheric pressure.
 
The pressure on Venus is nearly one thousand times higher than on Mars. As the atmosphere convects, descending gases warm and ascending gases cool. The amount of warming is determined primarily by the increase in pressure.
 
Ever used a bicycle pump? Why does it get hot?
 
Answer : Because you are doing work to the gas when you compress it. Similarly, solar radiation transfers energy to the atmosphere, causing convection and heating of sinking air. If there was no Sun, the atmosphere would be very cold and would in fact freeze.
 
The runaway greenhouse theory makes little sense. If it were true, the Earth would experience it from water vapour, not CO2. H2O is a much stronger greenhouse gas than CO2, is much more abundant than CO2 and gets released from the oceans very easily and often – particularly as the planet heats up.
