The first-year ice that survived the summer, now defined as second-year ice, will thicken through autumn and winter. However, it would take several more cool years in a row to build the ice cover back to the state it was in during the 1980s, which consisted of a larger proportion of thicker, multiyear ice that was more resistant to melt. While ice in the Arctic will thicken through this autumn and winter, winds may also transport some of the thicker ice out of the Arctic and into the N Atlantic.

This year was notably different. Because this year’s wind pattern was different than 2012, the multiyear ice largely remained in a compact area along the Canadian Archipelago and did not circulate into the Beaufort and Chukchi seas. The cooler conditions this summer also helped preserve more of the first-year ice through the summer.

Older, thicker ice remained in a region roughly between the North Pole and the Canadian Archipelago and the Greenland coast.

In recent summers, there has been considerable transport of older ice into the Beaufort and Chukchi seas, where it has been broken up and exposed to a warm ocean and high air temperatures. This has been a major factor in the loss of multiyear ice over the last decade.And

The pattern of ice thickness for the summer of 2013 is similar to what has been seen in recent years. According to data from the European Space Agency CryoSat-2 radar altimeter, the spring melt season started with an Arctic ice cover thinner than in any recent year. This corroborates thickness information inferred from a calculation of ice age that showed first-year ice, which is thinner and more vulnerable to melt, over a significant part of the Arctic Ocean as the melt season started. And

Over land, the cool spring resulted in greater than average March and April snow cover for the Northern Hemisphere. However, as in recent years, the snow melted rapidly, and by May, snow cover was at near record lows. Cooler weather conditions also limited surface melt on the Greenland Ice Sheet, which was still greater than the 1981 to 2010 average, but not near the record set in 2012. And

In contrast, this summer was characterized by unusually low pressure over much of the Arctic Ocean, which limited heat import from the south and brought more extensive cloud cover, keeping temperatures lower. In addition, the winds associated with the low pressure caused the ice cover to spread out and cover a larger area.

While 2012 and 2013 extents were similar through May, weather patterns from June to August helped retain more ice. Last summer was marked by lower than average pressure over the Eurasian side of the Arctic and higher than average pressure over Greenland. This resulted in a dipole-like wind pattern that favored ice transport across the ocean and the import of heat from southern latitudes along the Eurasian side of the Arctic. And

Contrasting weather conditions were a significant factor in this year’s higher sea ice extent and lower Greenland Ice Sheet melt intensity, compared to last year. This summer saw air temperatures at the 925 hPa level that were 1 to 3 degrees Celsius (2 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit) lower than last summer. It was also a cool summer compared to recent years over much of the Arctic Ocean, and even cooler than the 1981 to 2010 average in some regions, particularly north of Greenland. And

ERBE
The radiation budget represents the balance between incoming energy from the Sun and outgoing thermal (longwave) and reflected (shortwave) energy from the Earth.
In the 1970's, NASA recognized the importance of improving our understanding of ERB and its effects on the Earth's climate.
Langley Research Center was charged with developing a new generation of instrumentation to make accurate regional and global measurements of the components of the radiation budget.
science. larc.nasa.gov/erbe/

In 2003, Dr. Soon and his colleague at the SAO, Sallie Baliunas, published a now thoroughly debunked study in Climate Research’ "Proxy climatic and environmental changes of the past 1000 years," in the first of a number of denier challenges to Michael Mann’s ‘hockey stick’ study.
This study was republished [pdf] by the (then ExxonMobil funded) George Marshall Institute in 2003, though it was known Soon used moisture instead of temperature data.

While Dr. Soon and Dr. Baliunas acknowledged the American Petroleum Institute’s funding of the work in the paper, the dollar figure was not known. We now know from the newly acquired FOIA Smithsonian documents that the API gave them a total of $118,443 for this work, over 2002 and 2003, in grants entitled: “Sun's impact on climate over the last 1000 years” and “1000 years of solar variability.”

The Soon-Baliunas article claimed that the twentieth century was not the warmest century in the past 1,000 years and that the climate has not changed significantly during this time.
This sham science kicked off a heavy focus by deniers on the “hockey stick” study first done by Michael Mann, later proven sound by numerous other studies, but viciously attacked by deniers regardless.

"It really was one of the poorest pieces of scholarship that any of us in the climate research community had ever seen… it was clear that there was an effort by some on the editorial board to compromise the PR (peer review) process and allow through this deeply, deeply flawed paper in the professional literature where it was immediately held up by those in Washington opposed to taking action against climate change… it was just an extremely bad study that never should have published…" -Mann

Well, long before we measured the impact of CO2 on global temps we could calculate it:
The radiative forcing capacity (RF) is the amount of energy per unit area, per unit time, absorbed by the greenhouse gas, that would otherwise be lost to space. It can be expressed by the formula:
RF=100∑n-1Absi*Fi/(pathlength*density)
i represents an interval of 10 inv cm. Absi the integrated IR absorbance, and Fi the RF for that interval.
It is a mathematical certainty incrCO2= incrTemp

A carbon fee is a tax on fossil fuels based on their carbon content, which is proportional to the amount of CO2 they will produce when burned.  It's done that way because it's a lot easier to measure what comes out of the ground or is imported, than it is to measure the amount of CO2 emitted from each smokestack and tailpipe.  The fee can go to taxpayers in an equal per-capita green check.  Some prefer that some go to deficit reduction.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency definition of global warming:

“Global warming is an average increase in the temperature of the atmosphere near the Earth’s surface and in the troposphere, which can contribute to changes in global climate patterns. Global warming can occur from a variety of causes, both natural and human induced. In common usage, “global warming” often refers to the warming that can occur as a result of increased emissions of greenhouse gases from human activities.”

Despite getting 3.5x more sunlight, Mercury is only 0.46x as hot as Venus.  That's the difference a strong greenhouse effect makes. N2, O2, and Ar don't differentially absorb radiation: shortwave (solar) and longwave (terrestrial) are absorbed and emitted equally. CO2, on the other hand, doesn't absorb shortwave radiation much but absorbs lots of longwave. That means over 99% of the atmosphere isn't causing any warming, it's only the little concentrations like 390 parts per million of CO2. Small concentration, large effect.

I have friends and many major American cities, and they all say this is happening in their cities as well, so where is the connection between global warming and freezing cold weather? It seems like a bit of an oxymoron to me, granted I am not a scientist, and to be honest I know very little about the inner workings of global warming, can somebody who has factual evidence please fill me in on why it’s so cold here? I lived in the city for all of my 49 years and I’ve never seen anything like it, the Toronto Islands, which are a small group of islands in the Toronto harbour area, which is a public park, was close for most of the summer because the islands were under several feet of water, destroying almost everything on the island, causing hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenue and damage. It just doesn’t make any sense to me how all this connects to global warming.I have a friend that lives in Yellowknife, which is in the far Canadian North, she told me that it’s been absolutely freezing, and for the last 10 years the winters have been colder than I have ever experienced before, if that is so, then how is it that global warming exists? I know there are some studies to suggest that we tried several ice ages, so with that in mind, unless there was a civilization before us that we don’t know about, is it possible that all these events or nature doing what it does best, changing constantly with or without mankind interference? Like I said, I’m definitely not denying anything, I’m just extremely puzzled because what the scientist or telling us and what is really happening are so far apart it makes it very difficult to believe what they’re saying is true. First they said the Ozone layer was depleting in the arctic and we would all fry from no ozone to shield us, but they failed to mention that the hole in the ozone layer over the arctic was already there when we invented satellites and were able to take pics. Ozone production occurs when the suns rays make contact with Oxygen. The reason there isn't much ozone over the arctic is because 6 months a year is total darkness, and when there is sunlight, there is not much oxygen due to the lack of plants. Then they said Co2 was rising up and causing a canopy that trapped the heat and prevented it from escaping into space. They failed to mention that Co2 is heavier than air and cannot float up, but sinks down to ground level, but science doesn't mean anything to these idiots. When we started having record cold winters, the global warmers started looking stupid, so they changed their theory to climate change. It was no longer global warming, but climate change with extreme heat and extreme cold. Wait a minute, they're saying that a canopy of Co2 is trapping the earth's heat from escaping and this causes extreme cold? So the Co2 canopy takes a vacation in the winter and allows the heat to escape, causing extreme cold, but it returns in the summer? Co2 is not pollution, it's plant food and God made it heavier than air, so that it hovers near the ground to feed the plants. Co2 has a specific gravity of 1.5 while air has a specific gravity of 1.0. It is a scientific impossibility for Co2 to rise up and form a canopy. We have warmings in the US for people going into caves and underground storm drains for the risk of suffocation from elevated Co2 levels that displace the air. Look at dry ice, which is frozen Co2, and watch how it hovers near the ground when it warms and turns into a gas. Type in the you tube search "Co2 is heavier than air demonstration" and you'll see an elementary school science demonstration that shows it's impossible for Co2 to rise up.

Houston floods on a regular basis, that's nothing new, it's one of the most flood prone cities in the U.S..

We can also see the consensus in the fact that every single established academy of science, including the American Institute of Physics, that takes a position on man-made climate change, accepts that it's real and that it carries major risks to society.

*American Physical Society*
"The evidence is incontrovertible: Global warming is occurring. If no mitigating actions are taken, significant disruptions in the Earth’s physical and ecological systems, social systems, security and human health are likely to occur. We must reduce emissions of greenhouse gases beginning now." (November 2007)

*American Association for the Advancement of Science: AAAS*
"The scientific evidence is clear: global climate change caused by human activities is occurring now, and it is a growing threat to society." (December 2006)

*American Chemical Society*
"There is now general agreement among scientific experts that the recent warming trend is real (and particularly strong within the past 20 years), that most of the observed warming is likely due to increased atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, and that climate change could have serious adverse effects by the end of this century." (July 2004)

*U.S. National Academy of Sciences*
"The scientific understanding of climate change is now sufficiently clear to justify taking steps to reduce the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere." (2005)

Quezcatol - you have no idea how basic research is done.  all governments track various scientific data about their country from trees, air, animals, people...etc.  my dad tracked tuna fish numbers for the Australian government for 40 years.  His job security did not depend on his findings.   
so when you say "the more data I find for X the more money the government pay me to do more research into it" makes no sense for 2 reasons.  
1) Less can be More - in my dads case, the less of X (Tuna) could result in more funding.  
2) I don't get it - If there were less tuna and the government saw this as a problem and splashed out new round of funding, my dad would get none of it.  it would go to another scientist who will conduct experiments to find a solution.  
3) I still get paid - My dad was paid to just count the number of fish.  If the numbers are high or low, it didn't matter, he still got paid.  
4) Accuracy is Everything - the one thing that could get him fired, is if his numbers were not accurate.  His PhD was in pure mathematics.    He went to extraordinary lengths to make sure his numbers were right.  He would fly in statisticians to make sure the numbers were right before he published his results.
5) Scientist can criticise the government and keep their jobs. - My dad in the 80s disagreed with the Australian governments fishing policy and industry practices at the time.   After that, he worked for the government for another 30 years and was given awards by the fishing industry because his work was accurate.  

Same applies to climate scientist.

I hate to break it to you hoochy0208 but as part of the "CO2 amplification" hypothesis (and from the climate scientists themselves plainly stating it)...no matter CO2's impact on the temperature, before man's meddling (and of course barring massive eruptions), atmospheric CO2 levels were driven almost exclusively by temperature, not the other way around.  CO2 in the ice core record is effectively a proxy of ocean temperature, which is why it lags by hundreds of years.  Because of this you can't infer anything about CO2's impact on temperature from the CO2 levels in the ice core data.  You could even assume negative forcing from CO2 and so long as natural variation made temperatures fluctuate in the same way...CO2 would follow suit.

And BTW, this is why temperatures aren't showing anything remotely close to the response necessary to justify a statement like you made.  Were the tiny CO2 fluctuations of the glacial period capable of driving the changes of the glacial-interglacial transitions...the temperature would be going up by a couple tenths of a degree per year.

Scientists agree that CLIMATE CHANGES, always has and always will.  HOWEVER 97% of scientists have never agreed that mankind is the primary cause.  That "97%" that is always quoted is based on a questionnaire sent out to the scientific community by the UN that had the standard "mark totally agree, somewhat agree, totally disagree, somewhat disagree, or no opinion" to the comment (paraphrase)  "Mankind is responsible for current climate change". They then counted all who marked "totally agree, somewhat agree, somewhat disagree" as confirming the statement.  So the real question is "how much" or "to what degree" mankind affects climate change and a lot of scientists will say "very little".

Satellites have told the same story; see Mears et al. (2005).  When they corrected for certain aspects of the satellite orbit drift, the microwave temperature readings were consistent with surface readings.

The decrease in temperature as measured by satellites you are referring to is from papers published in the 1980s. These papers have been shown to have errors. To get an idea of average temperature using a satellite, the satellite would need to move over the same point at the same time for a number of days. The paper you're referring to did not include any adjustments to account for the fact that the satellites being used did not do this. Since then papers using satellites have shown an increase in average global temperature.

But that doesnt change the fact that climate change is real. The reason I can say this is because the climate is changing in such a way that it heavily affects foodcrops on global scale. (I am no expert in climate studies, but I am a expert in agriculture)

The ''myth'' that scientists agree is one of the most contested claims of the whole debate. Now, a lot of scientist that make up the ''its less than 97%'' claims do not have climate change as their field of expertise. It is easy to scew the % by including or excluding scientists from different fields. Someone can be great at physics, and know jack shit about the rather subtle enviromental changes as a result of climate change. That science is not a democracy is indeed a good observation, which is why disbelieve in science in our democratic society is something that can be really harmfull.

"Argueing against climate change"
That's the most common trick to discredit skeptics, change their argument a little bit to make them look stupid. No one is arguing against climate change, some people are arguing if human caused the change or not and/or if it's really that terrible. A common myth is that climate never has changed so fast, which is wrong [https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abrupt_climate_change]. Another common myth is that 97% of scientists agree. The people who claim that just count scientific papers and check if they agree or not. For 2 reasons that's not accurate and scientist who agree just publish more. 1st the media created the myth that it's a fact and everyone who argues against it must be an idiot. Publishing a paper that Doesn't agree will kill your reputation. 2nd there is conveying money if you sign  up a study related to global warming. Still most scientists agree but the true number is around 60-88%. So 12-40% deny a significant human influence (depending on source and how "deny" is defined) which is a decent controversable topic, unlike media represents it.

Also keep in mind science is not democracy. The majority was wrong in the past several times, which of course doesn't proof that the minority is right. But it shows it's possible that the minority is right. But most random guys that watched 2 documentaries suddenly are experts and know everything about climate...
